I'm not sure, if  @chrisgilmerproj did something different, but for me it seems to work with using `pull_request_target`. You just don't see the action on the implementing pull-request. (As your PR thinks it's done on base-branch, while base-branch thinks it's done on PR üòÑ)
For small extra security, i set the base-branch to be master, so people will not be able to create a PR onto another PR (but that is an extra gimmick to what was earlier).
See https://github.com/nextcloud/forms/pull/854 and https://github.com/nextcloud/forms/pull/855 for my considerations, if it really works in production we'll see probably next week. üôà 

EDIT: After reading the comments by @alexwilson, i probably need to double check the event. - So no guarantee this works.

In my action, which pairs nicely with this one, I moved to using the `labeled` event for `pull_request_target` and explicitly removed any checked-out code: https://github.com/alexwilson/enable-github-automerge-action/blob/main/.github/workflows/auto-merge-dependabot.yml

There's also a more practical example of this in a single workflow here: https://github.com/alexwilson/frontend/blob/master/.github/workflows/auto-approve.yml

Both, so far,¬†are working as before - and while the communication from GitHub wasn't ideal it was a useful exercise because it encouraged me to think about 3rd party code having access to secrets.  @JakeChampion made an excellent recommendation to lock 3rd party actions to a specific commit hash since they are (in-theory) immutable which reduces risk even further.

The key thing to consider is: A lot of this depends on the `actor` firing the event.

If it's a bot `dependabot` - both `pull_request` and the new `pull_request_target` with the default `created` & `edited` events **will _not_ allow read-access to secrets**.

The `labeled` event for `pull_request_target`, however, _does_ allow this as it is restricted to those with label access - and only special cases (i.e. `dependabot` or other explicitly installed apps) are still able to label PRs despite not having full access to the repository.  So it is "safer".

And it triggers a workflow, with read-access to secrets, and in read/write scope (e.g. the `GITHUB_TOKEN` allows one to issue an automatic approval - [you can see an example of this here](https://github.com/alexwilson/enable-github-automerge-action/pull/24)).  

Another change I made here - is checking for the creator of the pull-request, not the actor associated with an event, so that the action can be re-triggered & debugged manually.  If / when this action fails again, I'll be able to re-trigger the workflow and since the original creator was `dependabot` - it works as normal.
```yaml
    if: github.event.pull_request.user.login == 'dependabot[bot]'
```

Following all of this - [I added a disclaimer & adjusted the docs for the `enable-github-automerge` action](https://github.com/alexwilson/enable-github-automerge-action#2-usage), and highly recommend you do the same here @hmarr (or anyone else wishing to contribute to this excellent action) üòÑ

> I believe the idea is to ensure that if someone forks your repo and makes a PR back that they can't run a Github Action that includes code that can exfiltrate your secrets. I see this as an odd kind of hack but worth keeping in mind for this type of tool.

@skjnldsv 
I tried to answer this above - you are fine with an open contributing policy - the primary restriction is you should probably be using `pull_request_target` for any workflows that need to write back to your repo _because_ pull-request-target operates in the base branch (i.e. 3rd party code cannot accidentally run!).

If you need to _also_ do something with the code itself (i.e. run tests) - `pull_request` actions run _without any secrets_ in the branch being PR'd and you can run these in parallel.  For more complicated edge-cases (i.e. you want to provide a BrowserStack token to do some E2E testing) GitHub's recommendation is you invoke these workflows manually _after_ auditing the code.

In the context of my action & this one - I don't think that enabling either of these for 3rd parties is wise - you probably shouldn't be approving unaudited code - BUT if you would like to, `pull_request_target` triggered by humans will work.

@jotoeri 
The docs are awfully confusing - this is intel pieced together from a Github Support thread, many pages of docs, and the two blog posts GitHub have on this.  I'm feeding back in the support thread, so hopefully this will be clarified.

The intent is as you summarised however - so if you bear that in mind you should be okay!

> But for me, even with `pull_request_target`, it doesn't work, I have a `action triggered outside of a pull_request` error ü§î

@skjnldsv I saw this on the auto-merge-action, as it supports the `pull_request_target` only since a few days. If we bump `ahmadnassri/action-dependabot-auto-merge` to `@v2` it works. (or specific commit, as alex mentioned).

Sorry for taking a while to get to this! **I think switching from `pull_request` to `pull_request_target` should work.** I'm pretty sure that the read-only tokens introduced last month should only apply to Dependabot pull requests triggered by `pull_request` events. Switching to `pull_request_target` will run the workflow in the target branch (e.g. `main` rather than the PR's branch), but that's not a problem for this action as it just leaves a review and doesn't look at the code in the pull request. I tried both, and confirmed that `pull_request_target` does work as expected: #### `pull_request` [This actions run](https://github.com/hmarr/auto-approve-test/runs/2116761899?check_suite_focus=true) was triggered using the `pull_request` event, and it failed because the token only had `read` access to pull requests. #### `pull_request_target` [This action](https://github.com/hmarr/auto-approve-test/runs/2116761884?check_suite_focus=true) was triggered using `pull_request_target` event. It worked as expected. I'm adding some [more useful error messages](https://github.com/hmarr/auto-approve-action/blob/ce1c7f0f08b012f021130d2618caf6ca4d614e13/src/approve.ts#L36-L40), which should help folks catch this in the future. **If you're seeing "Resource not accessible by integration" with a workflow file (in a public repo) that _already_ has been switched over to `pull_request_target`, can you point me to the actions run?** I don't think that should be happening, so if it is I'd like to investigate. _Aside: I don't think the linked [Security Lab blog post](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests) is relevant. It raises a security issue associated with checking out potentially vulnerable code in the course of an Actions workflow, which this action doesn't do._

Thank you for helping with this ticket @hmarr . I believe you are correct that switching to `pull_request_target` fixes it. I'm going to close this and hopefully other folks will be able to use it for updating their own code.

Glad to hear it's working!

Hi there! `secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN` is a token that's [automatically provided](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/configuring-and-managing-workflows/authenticating-with-the-github_token#about-the-github_token-secret) to Actions workflows - anything that uses that token (such as approving the pull request) will appear as the "github-actions" user.

If you want to change the approving user, you can provide a [personal access token](https://docs.github.com/en/github/authenticating-to-github/creating-a-personal-access-token).

> Hi there! `secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN` is a token that's [automatically provided](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/configuring-and-managing-workflows/authenticating-with-the-github_token#about-the-github_token-secret) to Actions workflows - anything that uses that token (such as approving the pull request) will appear as the "github-actions" user.

I actually ran into this same issue... and "fixing" it (step 1 below) caused a more dangerous issue that I fortunately caught pretty quickly (step 2 below).

1. Add *the user that owns the `GITHUB_TOKEN` your are using for the workflow* to your `CODEOWNERS` file like so:

    ```config
    package.json @token-user
    yarn.lock @token-user
    ```
2. Ensure that only pull requests marked for automatic merge get approvals:

   ```yaml
   - uses: hmarr/auto-approve-action@v2.0.0
     if:
       (github.actor == 'dependabot[bot]' || github.actor == 'dependabot-preview[bot]')
       && contains(github.event.pull_request.body, 'will automatically merge')
   ```

---

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: make sure you add the `contains(github.event.pull_request.body, 'will automatically merge')` condition, otherwise @dependabot-preview will merge all pull requests that it opens because they all receive an approval from a code owner without that condition.

@hmarr it might be worth adding this information to the `README`, let me know if you'd like me to open a PR to do so!
@jrolfs Out of interest, what defines a PR to 'automatically merge'?
Any update on this? @jrolfs GITHUB_TOKEN is automatically injected by the GitHub action. So how to know who owns the token?
Is there a way to check if the user who opened the PR is also an owner of all files changed in the PR and approve accordingly with a bot which is an owner of all files in the repo?

As @jrolfs pointed out, you'll need to provide this action with the personal access token for a user who's listed as a code owner. It doesn't seem like it's possible to set a bot as a code owner.

I also just [added this to the README](https://github.com/hmarr/auto-approve-action#code-owners).

@dudicoco you could write a workflow that initially checks the codeowners for the changed files using a tool like this: https://github.com/hmarr/codeowners, then if that step succeeds, approve the PR using this action. As mentioned above, you'd need a bot user rather than using the `GITHUB_TOKEN` to pass a CODEOWNERS file check.

Turns out, removing the `branches` filter makes the action run correctly. Maybe the API changed?

The following example works!

```yml
name: Autoapprove

on:
  pull_request:

jobs:
  autoapprove:
    name: Autoapprove dependabot PRs
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: hmarr/auto-approve-action@v2.0.0
        if: github.actor == 'dependabot[bot]' || github.actor == 'dependabot-preview[bot]'
        with:
          github-token: ${{ secrets.AUTOAPPROVE_TOKEN }}
```

The `branches` filter seems to be for the destination branch, not the source branch as the example code in the README seems to assume.  I can't find if there's a way to filter based on the source branch.

Thanks for the pull request!

I think this might be better off as a separate action (such as [this one](https://github.com/pascalgn/automerge-action)). As actions can be composed in a workflow file, I think it's probably better to keep individual actions relatively small and simple. 

Using the example I linked above, the relevant section of the workflow file should end up looking something like this:

```yaml
    - uses: hmarr/auto-approve-action@v2.0.0
      if: github.actor == 'dependabot[bot]' || github.actor == 'dependabot-preview[bot]'
      with:
        github-token: "${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}"
    - uses: pascalgn/automerge-action@v0.4.0
      if: github.actor == 'dependabot[bot]' || github.actor == 'dependabot-preview[bot]'
      with:
        github-token: "${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}"
```

If that doesn't work out, let me know and I'll reconsider this!

I don't think that's possible. From https://help.github.com/en/articles/events-that-trigger-workflows#about-workflow-events:

> An action in a workflow run can't trigger a new workflow run. For example, if an action pushes code using the repository's GITHUB_TOKEN, a new workflow will not run even when the repository contains a workflow configured to run when push events occur.

I assume this is to prevent infinite chains of actions being triggered.
Thanks for the answer!

Now that Github Actions has the [workflow_dispatch event](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/reference/events-that-trigger-workflows#workflow_dispatch), I think it _is_ possible to trigger one workflow from another. So I would love it if this action took an optional input for the pull request number, because then it can be used from a workflow that executes on the `workflow_dispatch` event.

FYI, here's a quick and dirty action I created to do this with `cURL`.
https://github.com/kjvalencik/github-actions

```yaml
name: Auto-Approve Dependabot
on:
    - pull_request
jobs:
    build:
        runs-on: ubuntu-latest
        steps:
            - uses: kjvalencik/github-actions/approve@master
              if: github.event_name == 'pull_request' && github.actor == 'kjvalencik'
              env:
                GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
                GITHUB_SHA: ${{ github.sha }}
                GITHUB_PR_SELF: ${{ github.event.pull_request._links.self.href }}
```

This could probably be done with a simple bash action as well.

First, thansk for this awesome action!

I encountered an error with this PR:
```
Resource not accessible by integration
```

I think it has to do with private repositories. Maybe the provided access token does not allow that action.
You can use `target_branch` instead or create a personal token that is granted access (I'm not sure. I don't have a Pro account).

Why do I need to set `target_branch`, if this PR changes the detection of the **source** branch?
Also there doesn't seem to be an option to specify the source branch.

I fixed it by using 2.1.0.

The **source** branch of GitHub Pages is the **target** branch of this action. This action built to a branch, and then GitHub Pages deployed from the branch. Setting `target_branch` doesn't need to detect the source branch of GitHub Pages.

[The default token `GITHUB_TOKEN` doesn't have permission to access "pages".](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/reference/authentication-in-a-workflow#permissions-for-the-github_token) Maybe setting a token which has the permission can fix this problem. Sorry for my thoughtless of the case of private repositories.
ü§î  I don't really understand why `private` or `public` should make a difference here. I'll try to build a test case to check this.
In the meantime, I have reverted the `v2` tag to `2.1.0`.

Update: If following guide on the jekyll site, use this optional argument in your workflow:

```
    # Specify the target branch (optional)
    - uses: helaili/jekyll-action@v2
      env:
        JEKYLL_PAT: ${{ secrets.JEKYLL_PAT }}
      with:
        target_branch: 'gh-pages'
```

While reading the code, it looked like that this error appears only when pushing from the master branch in user.github.io repositories. Changing the name of the branch & pushing from it solved this error.
For simple Git repos without Gitflow, `master` is the default branch. So I'm not keen on renaming my default branch to work around this bug. Can this be fixed?

Now I get it! This plugin uses a heuristic to determine the target branch:

* If the repository ends with `.github.io`, it pushes to the `master` branch.
* Otherwise, it pushes to the `gh-pages` branch.

If the target branch is identical with the source branch, the plugin aborts with the message "::error::Cannot publish on branch <target branch>".

I didn't realize that GitHub used different branch naming conventions for "regular" repos and `.github.io` repos.

On re-reading your README file, I realized that it actually mentions this behavior, though I didn't understand it initially. It might be helpful to go into a bit more detail in the README file so that others won't stumble here.
Also, it would be great if I could explicitly configure the target branch, overriding the default heuristic!

@DanielSWolf this heuristic is somehow precise regarding the protocol GitHub uses to offer a static page for repositories. If you push the static files of your site in any branch except the `master` while this is a `"user".github.io"` repo, it won't be published. For this kind of repo, GitHub requires the static files to be in the `master` branch.

Otherwise, for non-user repo, GitHub uses the `gh-pages` branch by default (although they allow us to change which branch to publish, if I'm not wrong). Maybe in this case the `jekyll-action` code should have an ENV var to allow the changing of branch to push, if it doesn't already have it.

Just to summarize the behavior
- For `<user>.github.io` repos a user of that action **needs** to work on a branch different to `master`
- When not working on a `<user>.github.io` repo it's allowed to work on the `master`-branch and the plugin will create a `gh-pages`-branch by default

Not working on `master` is strange for me, even it's just a definition. So would also like to see an option to configure the target-branch or somehow disable that logic for `<user>.github.io`-repos. In the end it's also just a configuration inside the GitHub Pages to define a different branch as source.

I'll also stick with the older version for the moment.

Nice to see you here @elstudio. I don't have any strong feelings about Ruby versions. Any chance this could be a breaking change for existing users of this action?

Hi @helaili ‚Äî 

The TL;DR: Ruby 2.6 is probably more compatible with more Jekyll plugins (and more `Gemfile.lock` bundles) than the 2.7 version this action uses currently.

But your question is a good one! And I‚Äôm not sure of the best answer.

- This PR simply uses a Ruby 2.6 image, which is a good guess for the moment (more widely compatible with Jekyll plugins than 2.7 right now), but may not work for everybody.
- Systems seem to ship with the Bundler version that was current for the particular version of Ruby. So Alpine with Ruby 2.6 ships with Bundler 1.17, and 2.7 with Bundler 2.1.
- Folks who use modern best practices like `rbenv` can install multiple Ruby versions with the proper version of Bundler for each. But this is perhaps not common knowledge among those starting out with Jekyll.

The problem is this: when you do a `bundle install` the version of Bundler gets written into `Gemfile.lock` ‚Äî which means that if you committed a lock file written by one version of Bundler, the install using a different Bundler version will conk at the install step.

I don‚Äôt know how commonplace it is to have mismatched Ruby and Bundler versions, but Bundler 2.1 will install on older Rubys like 2.6, so it‚Äôs possible.

@michaelcurran is working around this by parsing `Gemfile.lock` directly: https://github.com/helaili/jekyll-action/issues/16#issuecomment-639323754

Longer term though, would it be better to let folks choose their Ruby version by reading `.rbenv` file or some other means? Maybe. But that‚Äôs harder to do with a Docker-based action ‚Äî especially since the Actions runners already provide a quick install route for different Ruby versions.

A different way to address this is to use the Rubys that are already available on the Actions runner, using the `ruby/setup-ruby` action in a workflow like this.

	- name: üíé setup ruby
	  uses: ruby/setup-ruby@v1
	  with:
	    ruby-version: 2.6
	
	- name: Jekyll build
	  run: |
	    bundle install
	    bundle exec jekyll build

With this approach, folks who need Ruby 2.7 can just specify it ‚Äî and they get the proper version of Bundler automagically. And the version is saved in the workflow, version controlled along with `Gemfile.lock`. 

You can see the entire workflow, which includes caching and publishing here: [https://github.com/universal-exports-ltd/slide-heroes/blob/master/.github/workflows/jekyll-build.yml](https://github.com/universal-exports-ltd/slide-heroes/blob/master/.github/workflows/jekyll-build.yml).

But this is a completely different architecture than the Docker action you have here.

We actually had a similar architectural discussion in #17 with @limjh16 and it came down to a tradeoff between flexibility, speed and simplicity. It's like the CAP theorem, you can't get all of them. Your `run` based solution has maximum flexibility, @limjh16's great for speed and this one is just dead simple. I should probably reference [your workflow](https://github.com/universal-exports-ltd/slide-heroes/blob/master/.github/workflows/jekyll-build.yml) in the documentation in order to provide an alternative path to people with specific needs. 

On the Ruby version side, I ran [a quick check with my sample site](https://github.com/helaili/jekyll-action/runs/755424857?check_suite_focus=true) and it did fail, so my thinking is although your change is probably right, I need to find a way to maintain a 2.6 (for new users) and 2.7 (legacy) path.

Thanks for this @gilesvangruisen! Can I ask you why going this way (i.e. writing code) as opposed to just adding a CNAME file to the source of your Jekyll site?

I have added a `CNAME-SAMPLE` in [my source sample website](https://github.com/helaili/jekyll-action/tree/master/sample_site) and it gets copied to the target. I think a documentation approach is much better (and definitely needed) - less code means less bugs and less maintenance üòÑ

I also have configured a custom domain via the repository settings, and this PR is related to this issue I just opened: https://github.com/helaili/jekyll-action/issues/46

Documentation like "Hey your custom domain will break unless you add this file" would be good as there's no clear way indicated in the docs to configure a custom domain. I can give `CNAME-SAMPLE` a try and see if it works.

I've verified that adding a `CNAME` file to the repository works to retain the custom domain, and this domain setting is propagated to the repo settings page. 

Considering there are multiple ways to configure your custom domain (via CNAME file as well as via the repository settings page), I think that this project should include information about this in the documentation if you prefer to not maintain code. 

Either way, without explicitly stating how to work with custom domains, your action breaks sites that use custom domains that are configured via the project settings page. Adding either this code change or some documentation would be great to improve the user-friendliness of this action.

I would agree that documentation would be a better approach‚Äîa code approach like this means that if I provide both a `CNAME` file and the configuration option, then the results could be confusing. On projects with multiple developers, this could possibly happen.

A regular Jekyll build would copy the `CNAME` file and then your changes would run the command `echo "domain.com" > CNAME` which would add a new line to the end of the existing CNAME file, having the file have 2 lines. Not sure what that would end up looking like in the repository settings but I imagine this being a source of confusion and it creating some questions like: "I added a CNAME file why isn't it working?" or "I added the config `github_pages_custom_domain` in the action's yaml, why isn't it working?" Probably best to use only one way (CNAME file) and specify explicitly in the docs how to use this action to support custom domains.

@tinacious thanks for the comments, and sorry for the delay! I'm updating this now with documentation about adding a `CNAME` file. 

I could be wrong, but I don't believe there's anything special with the Custom Domain setting in the Repository Settings. As far as I know, setting that field will create a file called `CNAME` on the selected branch, with the contents being the custom domain you entered. If you select the deployment branch, the file will be added, but this action will overwrite it on next deploy. So, the solution is either to ensure you're selecting the `master` or `main` branch when updating the Repository Settings' Custom Domain, or to create and commit the file yourself if you're running your GitHub Pages site from an alternate branch.
Thanks @tinacious and @gilesvangruisen. Let me know if it's ready to be merged.

Anyway, what about adding an extra step in the workflow and execute the Algolia step separately? Based on [this blog](https://cristianpb.github.io/blog/jekyll-algolia), I would try something like:

- uses: actions/checkout@v2

          ruby-version: 2.6.x

Solved it! Thanks a lot!

Hey Alain, Kia Ora @kinow,

I'm the author of the jekyll-algolia plugin (but don't maintain it anymore), and I can confirm that it requires a second step after building the website.

I made `jekyll algolia` a different step instead of baking it into `jekyll build` because often you want to decouple both. You might build your website often (for testing, for pull requests, for fixing a typo, etc), but you might want to avoid eating all your Algolia credits quota for that and *only* index when everything else is working.

Glad you could work out your issue in the end :)
Thanks for explaining and thanks for the Algolia action!

Hey! When you add a custom domain from GitHub Pages settings directly, it commits a CNAME file to master branch. However, every time this action runs, if your repository is *.github.io it overwrites the master branch. Thus you'll need to manually create a CNAME file in your source branch. For your case, I think this branch is named "blog".

Thank you so much, @limjh16. I had no idea about that :-)

Instead of checking in a CNAME in my repository, I updated my build workflow instead. After `- uses: actions/checkout@v2` I added this:

	- uses: finnp/create-file-action@master
	  env:
	    FILE_NAME: "./blogfiles/CNAME"
	    FILE_DATA: "my.custom.domain.com"
	
It works beautifully.

There is already a `jekyll_src` parameter for this action (see [the code sample](https://github.com/helaili/jekyll-action#use-the-action) in the `README`). Is it similar?

`jekyll_src` parameter is passed as `--source` to `jekyll`. `bundle`, which is invoked earlier, still expects Gemfile to reside in the root folder. I'm keeping everything related to static site in it's own directory, so `jekyll_src` is of no help for me (see https://github.com/inkremental/inkremental/tree/master/docs for the reference).

Both my and @abhishekmit1982 take is to add an option to change the directory entirely before running other commands. The downside is the fact that `vendor/bundle` cache is also moved, one should change it's location to some well-known location.

@limjh16 proposed another interesting option of passing additional `--gemfile` parameter to `bundle`. I've just tried this, it seems to be working as expected with some changes to parameters:
```
bundle update --gemfile docs/Gemfile 
bundle exec --gemfile docs/Gemfile jekyll serve -s docs -d docs/_site
```
I'm not seeing any downsides to it, there are no files in the root directory after running this. So I'm actually leaning to it. Unfortunately `jekyll_src` doesn't tweak Jekyll output directory, and making it so would be a breaking change. Also Gemfile location tweaking could be either relative to working directory or `jekyll_src` value.

WDYT?

How can I fix this issue?

It's basically because your source and your target are both set to `master`, so publishing would overwrite the source. 

Move the source to a different branch, and trigger the workflow when a push happens on this branch. `master` will then contain the generated version of your site, and you should never commit on this branch as it will be overwritten eventually.

The problem you are running into is described [here](https://bundler.io/blog/2019/05/14/solutions-for-cant-find-gem-bundler-with-executable-bundle.html).

Thanks that link is relevant. I see it's a bug.

I added that bundle line in my Gemfile as an experiment solution but it meant the error was the same as without it. The reason yours works is your lock file  bundler matches your container's bundle version. I could upgrade mine but then my other projects need to match my new system version. And then I'm always tied to the version of this action. (Or I edit or drop my lock file.)

That's why I suggested a workflow param so then the build steps use an given bundler version. e.g. 1.17.2

A larger change would be to drop bundler use for the action. Netlify does great with `jekyll build` and no bundler (and it insists on a lock file existing). So just an idea to consider one day if bundler gives other hassles

Hey,
According to the [bundler 2 upgrade page](https://bundler.io/guides/bundler_2_upgrade.html#version-autoswitch), The version of Bundler in the BUNDLED WITH section in Gemfile.lock is read by Bundler to determine which version of Bundler should run, so not really sure why the error still pops up..?
Also, Netlify also uses bundler (see https://community.netlify.com/t/builds-bundler-version-from-gemfile-lock-now-installed-and-used/5561). I think it would be difficult to manage a Gemfile without it.

Hi, I've solved the issue using a fork and feature branch and would like to share here. üöÄ 

I set a custom `BUNDLER_VERSION` variable in my workflow file's `env`. And that gets used in `Dockerfile`. And if the value is not set, then `Dockerfile` falls back to hardcoded value of `2.1.4`.

https://github.com/MichaelCurrin/jekyll-action/pull/1

I tested my solution by setting `1.17.3` in my sample `test.yaml` workflow file and changing the lockfile use to `1.17.3`. There are no errors like in my original comment at the top of this issue and the site builds.

---

Notes

- Perhaps there's a better way to set/validate if this using `inputs` rather than `env`, like for`jekyll_src`. On that, is `jekyll_src` actually used and test? It gets set as an input with `inputs.jekyll_src` but then `INPUT_JEKYLL_SRC` is used in entry point script and I can't see how that is set.
- For background, I got idea from this [PR](https://github.com/spinnaker/spinnaker.github.io/pull/1573/files) based on few projects linked [here](https://github.com/docker-library/ruby/issues/246) and it does an explicit install of bundler.

Regarding the `JEKYLL_SRC`, it is resolved automatically based on the directory that contains `_config.yml`. You can overload this behavior by setting it yourself with the input. 

Did you see @limjh16's [comment](https://github.com/helaili/jekyll-action/pull/17#issuecomment-618144684) on #17? Seems like there is another interesting solution.

It was only to demonstrate that you can find code even if the code doesn't contain a docstring. 
 We wanted to emphasize that you can build a representation of code in the same space as natural language even if the code doesn't contain natural language such as comments or docstrings.

  In practice, if we are trying to build a real semantic search system we would definitely find another way (perhaps using a separate encoder) to learn a representation of the docstring as well and have that be considered as well as the code representation.

@ajay-sreeram here is general intuition:

When you freeze model you have less trainable parameters and thus you can push more data through the computation graph without running out of memory.   This is why when we unfreeze the model we decrease the batch size dramatically.

üëã thanks for opening this issue, @ryanb. ‚ú® 

> If I have a list of a hundred items which all reference the same `inline_svg_tag` image, the content is duplicated for each item.

Do you have a (simplified) example? I would like to understand how the list of items is constructed, the structure of the SVG and the surrounding HTML document if possible. ü§î 

> Is this something that fits in the scope of `inline_svg`? I understand if not, but it seems like a nice feature.

I'm not 100% sure if this fits the scope of `inline_svg` but I'm hoping some example code will help to clarify that a little.

@jamesmartin Sure, something along these lines: ```
    <% 100.times do %>
  • <%= inline_svg_tag "handle.svg" %> Item
    • <% end %>
``` Here the content of the `handle.svg` is inlined for every list item. If it's a complex SVG this could result in significantly larger HTML. It's possible to reference part of another SVG using an id like this: ```
    <% 100.times do %>
  • Item
    • <% end %>
``` This way the SVG content is outside of the repeating content. This is similar to the first attempt taken by GitHub mentioned in [this blog post](https://github.blog/2016-02-22-delivering-octicons-with-svg/#our-approach). Looks like they had cross-domain issue preventing them from doing this, but many don't have that issue. Perhaps it's not worth the hassle of referencing external SVG icons since most of them are small. Just an idea. :)

@ryanb thanks for the examples, that does seem like a useful feature, especially if there is no cross-domain problem in your use-case. Based on your second example, which is no doubt simplified for clarity, how do you imagine the `inline_svg` API would work? The simplest thing I can of is to pass the collection to `inline_svg`, which would render the SVG document first, setting the `display:none` style (presumably), and then yield each item of the collection to the block, like this: ```ruby
    <%= (inline_svg_tag "handle.svg", with_use_tag: 100.times) do |item| %>
  • <%= item %>
    • <% end %>
``` This assumes the caller would assemble their own slim SVGs in the block, with the relevant `` tag. I'm not sure if this actually buys you much though. I feel like I'm still missing something here. ü§î

> how do you imagine the inline_svg API would work? 

@jamesmartin good question. In my example I included the svg on the same page but I think it would be better done through a separate URL which could join multiple svgs together, perhaps join everything within a directory similar to how a sprite library works.

```
# app/assets/images/icons/handle.svg
# app/assets/images/icons/login.svg
# app/assets/images/icons/profile.svg
# app/assets/images/icons/settings.svg
```

Behind the scenes this would generate an `app/assets/images/icons.svg` file (maybe through a configuration) which would combine all of the files in the directory under one svg and auto-generate a unique id for each one based on the filename.

```
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <symbol id="handle" viewBox="0 0 14 14">...</symbol>
  <symbol id="login" viewBox="0 0 14 14">...</symbol>
  <symbol id="profile" viewBox="0 0 14 14">...</symbol>
  <symbol id="settings" viewBox="0 0 14 14">...</symbol>
</svg>
```

Then you could do `<%= inline_svg_use_tag "icons/handle.svg" %>` which could output something like this:

```
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="14" height="14"><use href="assets/icons.svg#handle" /></svg>
```

The `icons.svg` file could be cached by the browser similar to images so we have all icons under one request and the generated HTML is very slim.

I understand if this is outside the scope of `inline_svg` since it involves some asset pipeline magic. Would be cool to have though.

**Update:** Looks like there are a number of solutions already out there to help with this.
* [svgeez](https://github.com/jgarber623/svgeez)
* [svg-sprite-loader](https://github.com/JetBrains/svg-sprite-loader)
* [svg-spritemap-webpack-plugin](https://github.com/cascornelissen/svg-spritemap-webpack-plugin)

I'm interested in this also, although I see the API as an "inline" solution (not assets pipeline).  Here's what I'm thinking.

1. Add per request caching to getting svg files (good optimization to add, regardless of `use` tag.)

```diff
module Helpers
  def inline_svg_tag(filename, transform_params={})
    with_asset_finder(InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder) do
-     render_inline_svg(filename, transform_params)
+     cache_inline_svg(filename, transform_params)
    end
  end

+ def cache_inline_svg(*args)
+   @svg_files ||= {}
+   @svg_files[args] ||= render_inline_svg(*args)
+ end
...
```

2. Look for `use` flag or `use_id` flag.  SVG use requires a unique id per svg sprite, so it would be a great developer experience to auto-create a unique id if they did not specify one.  However, use their id if they did specify one.

3. `inline_svg_tag` with `use` param returns:

   ```html
   <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
     <use href="#inline-svg-aircraft-a4zde5d" x="20" fill="white" stroke="red"/>
   <svg>
   ```

4. Finally, a helper method which combines the unique `@svg_files` into a single svg sprite. 

   ```erb
   <%= inline_svg_sprites_tag, style: 'display: none;' %>
   ```

    or

   ```erb
   <% content_for :svg_sprites do %>
       <%= inline_svg_sprites_tag %>
   <% end %>
   ```


   which renders something like

   ```html
   <svg style="display:none;">
     <symbol id="inline-svg-aircraft-a4zde5d" viewBox="0 0 62 51">
       <path fill="#000000" d="M38.9872..."></path>
     </symbol>
     <symbol id="inline-svg-attachment-de5da4z" viewBox="0 0 60 64">
       <path fill="#000000" d="M15.9264..."></path>
     </symbol>
     <symbol id="inline-svg-brush-hasd98w" viewBox="0 0 62 62">
       <path fill="#000000" d="M7.8416..."></path>
     </symbol>
     <symbol id="inline-svg-camer-8hx9rf" viewBox="0 0 64 52">
       <path fill="#000000" d="M32,19.2 ..."</path>
     </symbol>
   </svg> 
   ```

This would certainly speed up pages with lots of SVG files.

FYI, others are interested in this also.

Another idea I had was to modify some of the internals to accept a finder as an optional argument.

For example:

```ruby
module InlineSvg
  class FindsAssetPaths
    def self.by_filename(filename)
      asset = configured_asset_finder.find_asset(filename)
      asset.try(:pathname) || asset.try(:filename)
    end

    def self.configured_asset_finder
      InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder
    end
  end
end
```

becomes

```ruby
module InlineSvg
  class FindsAssetPaths
    def self.by_filename(filename, asset_finder: InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder)
      asset = asset_finder.find_asset(filename)
      asset.try(:pathname) || asset.try(:filename)
    end
  end
end
```

It would mean changing some internal API calls, but I think it could be done in a backwards-compatible way. It's more explicit and probably a cleaner approach than setting thread-specific variables.

@kylefox thanks for the write-up of this problem and suggestions for fixes. ‚ú® 

I like the idea of passing the `asset_finder` around. This should allow the Webpack and sprockets implementations to diverge where necessary.

> It would mean changing some internal API calls, but I think it could be done in a backwards-compatible way.

Hmmm ... after looking at the code more, I'm not sure it's possible to remain totally backwards-compatible. ü§î In order to pass the `asset_finder` all the wait down the chain, the method signature for asset file classes would need to change from `named(asset_name)` to `named(asset_name, asset_finder)`.

This is fine for built-in asset files ([`InlineSvg::AssetFile.named`](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/blob/master/lib/inline_svg/asset_file.rb#L6-L11) and [`InlineSvg::CachedAssetFile#named`](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/blob/master/lib/inline_svg/cached_asset_file.rb#L28-L31)), but _does_ present a problem for [custom asset file loaders](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#custom-asset-file-loader).

I'm wondering if we could:

1. Release a patch version using the aforementioned `Thread.current` fix. It's a bit ugly, but it works ‚Äî and is arguably less ugly than sporadically disappearing SVGs üòï 
2. Consider a new API for asset files/loaders in [Version 2.0](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/issues/1050) that eliminates the need for the `Thread.current` fix. Perhaps the internal and external APIs can be simplified, now that webpack is officially supported by Rails and this library supports both Sprockets and Webpacker simultaneously.

Thoughts @jamesmartin?

> I'm wondering if we could:
> 
> 1. Release a patch version using the aforementioned `Thread.current` fix. It's a bit ugly, but it works ‚Äî and is arguably less ugly than sporadically disappearing SVGs üòï
> 2. Consider a new API for asset files/loaders in [Version 2.0](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/issues/1050) that eliminates the need for the `Thread.current` fix. Perhaps the internal and external APIs can be simplified, now that webpack is officially supported by Rails and this library supports both Sprockets and Webpacker simultaneously.

@kylefox this sounds like a sensible way forward. Do you want to open a PR with your `Thread.current` hotfix so I can get that out as a patch?

```erb

Our application uses both `inline_svg_tag` (asset pipeline) and `inline_svg_pack_tag` (webpacker). I'm starting to wonder if [the changes I introduced](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/pull/103/files#diff-76810304c6563797234460d5732ea6b3R71-R79) to support both asset pipeline and webpacker in the same application are not thread-safe ü§î

For example, when `inline_svg_pack_tag` is executed, it temporarily sets `InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder = InlineSvg::WebpackAssetFinder`. If `inline_svg_tag` is executed _before_  `InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder` is reset to its initial value (after `inline_svg_pack_tag`) completes, is it possible that `inline_svg_tag` is _actually_  using `InlineSvg::WebpackAssetFinder`?

Thanks for opening this issue. ‚ú® Apologies that the cached asset file is not working as expected.

When using this in production I always use paths containing non-fingerprinted, "static", assets. When caching the assets in memory at boot time it's unnecessary for them to be fingerprinted because the browser will never request them directly and so there's no need for any cache-busting. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇ 

But‚Ä¶ I can definitely see why this is inconvenient, as it means assets must be either "static" _or_ fingerprinted but can't be both. üòû 

I doubt this works for non-Webpacker environments either.  

> I've been able to work around this by defining my own custom cached asset file class like so:
> 
> ```ruby
> class CachedWebpackAssetFile < InlineSvg::CachedAssetFile
>   def named(asset_name)
>     super(Webpacker.manifest.lookup(asset_name))
>   end
> end
> ```

Thanks for finding a workaround. Seems like there's a couple of options for how to fix this, but it's probably going to involve two lookups: first using the "static" name of the asset and falling back to the "fingerprinted" name (via `Webpacker.manifest.lookup` or whatever). The other option, to avoid doing two lookups, is to allow this to be configured by users (maybe an option like `use_fingerprinted_asset_names: true`) but I'm less happy about making users configure the library.

Yeah I'm honestly not sure what the ideal option is here. The workaround we have makes sense in an entirely Webpacker-world, but since the gem needs to support both Webpacker + Sprockets, it might need to get a bit "smarter" in its logic.

- This commit "Pull require pathname into sprockets/legacy.rb" moved the require:

Thanks for opening this issue, @rhymes. ‚ú® 

This seems like a reasonable request to me.

> One thing I'm curious about in general ‚Äî what other use-cases have you seen for using a custom `asset_finder`, besides webpacker support?

One concrete use-case is in situations where development versus production differ. For example, when [caching all SVG assets at Rails boot time](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#caching-all-assets-at-boot-time) it's useful to implement a separate asset finder for use in development mode to allow dynamic reloading from disk.

@kylefox thanks for the suggestion. I've been thinking about the upgrade path for existing Rails apps and I think your suggestion makes sense. Definitely open to the idea of multiple asset finders. üëç

Thinking about it more, I wonder if it makes sense to introduce a _new_ helper explicitly for webpacker ‚Äî similar to what Rails/Webpacker itself has done. ü§î

Rails has `image_tag` for images in the asset pipeline, and `image_pack_tag` for images in webpacker.

What do you think about replacing `inline_svg` with `inline_svg_tag` for the asset pipeline and `inline_svg_pack_tag` for webpacker?

I think those helpers more closely match the Rails helpers. `inline_svg` could be an alias for `inline_svg_tag` _or_ `inline_svg_pack_tag` (with a deprecation warning) depending on which `asset_finder` is currently configured.

> What do you think about replacing `inline_svg` with `inline_svg_tag` for the asset pipeline and `inline_svg_pack_tag` for webpacker?

I'm not against this. I think it would have to be a major version bump as it would completely break the v1.x interface. Sounds like v2.0 might be the "Webpacker" release. üòÜ

Yeah, I think for sure it would need to be a major version bump. Just wanted to confirm if you'd be open to a change like that (and the resulting major version bump) before I explored that route. Thanks!

> Just wanted to confirm if you'd be open to a change like that (and the resulting major version bump) before I explored that route.

I think the interface change you proposed will clear up confusion and make things more consistent with similar Rails internal helpers, so I'm definitely open to this and a major version bump as a result. üëç

  path_to_asset(current_webpacker_instance.manifest.lookup!(path), options)

  path_to_asset(current_webpacker_instance.manifest.lookup!(name), options)
end
```

Ideal is to have both finders work together. Of course check if webpack if available, if not only static finder works

> check if webpack if available

I think that may be a key problem for our case.

Our app uses *both* the asset pipeline and Webpack (via Webpacker) as we slowly migrate from the former to the latter. The two tools process completely independent sets of assets for us.

As I understand the problem, `app.instance_variable_get(:@assets)` returns `nil` in production because the assets have been precompiled. However, because we have Webpack, the `WebpackAssetFinder` is enabled. However, Webpack doesn't know about these assets, so when the SVG is requested the finder fails.

Prior to 1.5, the fallback would have gone to the static asset finder, which would find the precompiled assets .

@shepmaster thanks for clarifying that you're using both Sprockets _and_ Webpacker while you transition.

I added a note to the [readme](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/blob/e32d1f68f904921c8e50e21edbc9cab7bacd7db6/README.md#sprockets-and-webpacker) when I released 1.5.0 that was intended to help with any confusion, but it was not clear enough:

> If you have both Sprockets and Webpacker enabled for some reason and you want Inline SVG to use Webpacker to find SVGs then you should configure the asset_finder appropriately

I'm going to add a note about using the `StaticAssetFinder` if you precompile assets in production.

In your case I think it's sufficient to just configure the `StaticAssetFinder` explicitly until you decide whether Webpacker will be bundling your image assets:

```ruby
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.asset_finder = InlineSvg::StaticAssetFinder
end
```

Given this is a breaking change, I probably should have bumped the major version to 2.0. Apologies again for the disruption. ü§î 

> Ideal is to have both finders work together. Of course check if webpack if available, if not only static finder works

That's kind of a complicated problem because Webpacker doesn't expose any reliable method to ask, "is Webpacker bundling images". We *could* check the Webpacker manifest file and start greping for paths that appear to be images, but that's probably not very reliable.

I think I'm going to remove the auto-selection of Webpacker and make it "opt-in" for now. This is going to break too many Heroku Apps and it's not reasonable to make everybody do manual configuration to get back existing functionality.

I've released [v1.5.2](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/releases/tag/v1.5.2), which completely reverts the automatic Webpacker detection and makes Webpack "opt-in" by default, meaning that if you're using Sprockets to serve assets (either dynamically, or precompiled), there should be no additional configuration required.

Please update to this version and let me know if you have any problems. Sorry for all the trouble these last couple of releases have caused.

If someone else lands here with a similar problem. Here's how I've approached the issue. The following solution works with Webpacker, whether the dev server is running or the assets have been compiled to my public/ directory.

InlineSvg allows for creation of custom asset finders so that's what this does.

I'm fairly certain there may be a cleaner way to do this, but this works.

```ruby
# In config/initializers/inline_svg.rb
class WebpackerAssetFinder
  class FoundAsset
    attr_reader :path

    def initialize(path)
      @path = path
    end

    def pathname
      if Webpacker.dev_server.running?
        # The dev server is running. Load the SVG into a Tempfile.
        asset = open("#{Webpacker.dev_server.protocol}://#{Webpacker.dev_server.host_with_port}#{path}")

        tempfile = Tempfile.new(path)
        tempfile.binmode
        tempfile.write(asset.read)
        tempfile.rewind

        tempfile

      else
        # The dev server isn't running. The asset will be compiled to public.
        Rails.application.root.join 'public', path.gsub(/\A\//, '')

      end
    end
  end

  def find_asset(filename)
    if webpack_asset_path = Webpacker.manifest.lookup(filename)
      return FoundAsset.new(webpack_asset_path)
    end
  end
end

# Override the Sprockets asset finder.
InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder = WebpackerAssetFinder.new
```

I also ran into this. To get around it I had to make some changes to the solution @moxie posted above.

First, ensure you don't use `asset_pack_path` in your `inline_svg` call, otherwise the asset will not be found in the webpack manifest.

The next issue I had (likely because I have some nested paths), is that the creation of the `Tempfile` failed (and was caught by the gem, so the issue was hard to track down). I opted to leave off the `path` and just let it generate a unique filename for me.

Lastly, since I depend on both webpacker _and_ the asset pipeline, I ended up with a fallback approach.

Here's what I ended up with:

```ruby
class WebpackerAssetFinder
  class FoundAsset
    attr_reader :path

    def initialize(path)
      @path = path
    end

    def pathname
      if Webpacker.dev_server.running?
        asset = open(webpacker_dev_server_url)

        begin
          tempfile = Tempfile.new(path)
          tempfile.binmode
          tempfile.write(asset.read)
          tempfile.rewind
          tempfile
        rescue StandardError => e
          Rails.logger.error "Error creating tempfile: #{e}"
          raise
        end
      else
        Rails.application.root.join("public", path.gsub(/\A\//, ""))
      end
    end

    private

    def webpacker_dev_server_url
      "#{Webpacker.dev_server.protocol}://#{Webpacker.dev_server.host_with_port}#{path}"
    end
  end

  def find_asset(filename)
    if webpack_asset_path = Webpacker.manifest.lookup(filename)
      FoundAsset.new(webpack_asset_path)
    end
  end
end
```

Then in the `config/initializers/inline_svg.rb` initializer:

```ruby
class FallbackAssetFinder
  attr_reader :finders

  def initialize(finders)
    @finders = finders
  end

  def find_asset(filename)
    # try each finder, in order, return the first path found
    finders.lazy.map { |f| f.find_asset(filename) }.find { |x| x != nil }
  end
end

# Some of our SVG assets will be in the asset pipeline, some from webpacker,
# This allows us to find the SVGs for inlining in both cases.
InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder = FallbackAssetFinder.new([
  WebpackerAssetFinder.new,
  InlineSvg::StaticAssetFinder,
])
```

Hope this helps someone else trying to do the same thing. Thanks to @moxie for providing the basis for this workaround.

Added support for Webpacker in [v1.5.0](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/releases/tag/v1.5.0).

Webpacker is "opt-in" as of [v1.5.2](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/releases/tag/v1.5.2) because it was breaking users that were using both Sprockets with precompiled assets _and_ Webpacker: https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/issues/98#issuecomment-503774840

In case anyone comes across this, I've been fighting this config today and was able to get it working finally for Rail v6.0.0. The general idea of the previous exmples works, but I had to adapt it in two ways:



1. **Finding the asset**
   to support identifying the asset with or without the `media/images` path segments, I had to modify the lookup. You could do this in various more straightforward ways... but given I had the `hashie` dependency already, I went with the following quick update to maintain consistency with the [path formats accepted by the `asset_path_tag` helper](https://github.com/rails/webpacker/blob/master/docs/assets.md)

   ```ruby
   require 'hashie'
   
   def find_asset(filename)
     assets = Hashie::Rash.new(Webpacker.manifest.instance_variable_get('@data'))
     webpack_asset_path = assets[%r{(media\/images\/)?#{filename}}]
   
     return unless webpack_asset_path.present?
   
     WebpackerAssetFinder::FoundAsset.new(webpack_asset_path)
   end
   ```

   

2. **Reading the svg data**
   I was seeing this error when attempting acceses the resource on the dev server via `open` as in the above examples despite it being the correct location (I can visit it directly and see the content).

   ```
   Errno::ENOENT: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen http://localhost:3035/packs/media/i.....
   ```

   

   So, I make a request and get the data from the reponse... 

   ```ruby
   def pathname
     # The dev server is running. Load the SVG into a Tempfile.
     if Webpacker.dev_server.running?
       http = Net::HTTP.new(Webpacker.config.dev_server[:host], Webpacker.config.dev_server[:port])
       resp = http.get(path)
   
       return unless resp.code == '200'
   
       tempfile = Tempfile.new(path)
       tempfile.binmode
       tempfile.write(resp.body)
       tempfile.rewind
   
       tempfile
     # The dev server isn't running. The asset will be compiled to public.
     else
       Rails.application.root.join 'public', path.gsub(%r{\A\/}, '')
     end
   end
   ```

   convoluted, yes...works, yes.

   

   I personally don't want to support finding sprockets compiled assets, but extending this with @subdigital nice fallback approach would be straightforward.

Seeing as a lot of other people have looked into this, I figured I might as well tack on my own solution. It seems like the inline_svg implementation of the webpack svg resolver is similar to many of the examples here, so this is all it took for me to get it working properly in my own setup:

```ruby
class AppWebpackAssetFinder < InlineSvg::WebpackAssetFinder
  def initialize(filename)
    super(filename)
    @asset_path = Webpacker.manifest.lookup("media/svg/#{@filename}")
  end
end

class FallbackAssetFinder
  attr_reader :finders

  def initialize(finders)
    @finders = finders
  end

  def find_asset(filename)
    # try each finder, in order, return the first path found
    finders.lazy.map { |f| f.find_asset(filename) }.find { |x| x != nil }
  end
end

# Some of our SVG assets will be in the asset pipeline, some from webpacker,
# This allows us to find the SVGs for inlining in both cases.
InlineSvg.configuration.asset_finder = FallbackAssetFinder.new([
  AppWebpackAssetFinder,
  InlineSvg::StaticAssetFinder,
])
```
Caused by [inlining SVGs without the gem](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/issues/89#issuecomment-414267689).

One of the reasons for allowing [custom transformations](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/tree/8e9c3afff89838cc42f35ff97979d9747581e50e#custom-transformations) of SVGs is to keep the core code simple and easy to maintain, while allowing individual users to depend on third-party SVG optimizers if they choose.

Another strategy, involving even less runtime complexity, would be to optimize SVGs separately from this library, perhaps as part of the asset pipeline or other build/deploy step, which could then be [cached at boot time](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/tree/8e9c3afff89838cc42f35ff97979d9747581e50e#caching-all-assets-at-boot-time).

I'd be happy to help you get either or both of these strategies working but I'm not convinced that adding extra SVG optimization to the core of this library is a worthwhile feature.

Answering your questions, no I don't have any custom configuration, the only thing that I've added regarding InlineSvg is this configuration for the assets ``` Rails.application.config.assets.context_class.class_eval do include InlineSvg::ActionView::Helpers end ``` and this is how I'm using the `inlive_svg` method ``` <%= inline_svg('hub_v2/icons/Print.svg', class: 'print-link-icon') %> ```

I'm closing this issue since this has to do with [angular-rails-templates](https://github.com/pitr/angular-rails-templates). 

Turns out that the issue indeed was on tilt, it wasn't loading the helpers, so this is the code that I used as a workaround
```
module CustomERBEngine
  class ERBTemplate < Tilt::ERBTemplate
    def evaluate(scope, locals, &block)
      scope.class_eval do
        include Rails.application.routes.url_helpers
        include Rails.application.routes.mounted_helpers
        include ActionView::Helpers
        include InlineSvg::ActionView::Helpers
      end

end

Tilt.register CustomERBEngine::ERBTemplate, 'erb'

@JonaMX thanks for following up with a detailed description of the root cause and providing your workaround to help others that stumble on the same problem. üëç ‚ö°Ô∏è

> However, this breaks some tests since the resulting SVG code is taken directly from the asset file and is no longer returned in the beautifully consistent format that Nokogiri provides.

If I understand this correctly, and for what it matters, if the argument is code beautification over performance I would argue in favor of performance.

> If I understand this correctly, and for what it matters, if the argument is code beautification over performance I would argue in favor of performance.

Agreed. My chief concern with the change that I was experimenting with is that it would alter the behavior of the method slightly. In my very brief test I tried adding a short circuit into the `TransformPipeline.generate_html_from` method to avoid parsing the input with Nokogiri if there are no transformations:
```ruby
def self.generate_html_from(svg_file, transform_params)
  return svg_file.to_s unless transform_params.any? || Transformations.custom_transformations.any?
  ...
```

However, it alters the returned SVG markup slightly because it's no longer cleaned up by Nokogiri, as demonstrated by this failing spec:
```
InlineSvg::ActionView::Helpers#inline_svg when passed IO object argument return valid svg for file
     Failure/Error: expect(output).to eq "<svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" xml:lang=\"en\" role=\"presentation\"><!-- This is a test comment --></svg>\n"

       expected: "<svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" xml:lang=\"en\" role=\"presentation\"><!-- This is a test comment --></svg>\n"
            got: "<svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\"\n     xml:lang=\"en\"\n     role=\"presentation\"><!-- This is a test comment --></svg>\n"
```

This represents a change in behavior that some users of the gem may not be expecting. Also, the markup returned when you pass transformation options may be slightly different than when you do not pass options. It's a minor inconsistency, and I don't think it's a _huge_ issue, but I figured it was worth discussing before throwing it into a PR. üòÑ

@jamesmartin for custom attribute support, are there additional steps to take other than `"aria-hidden" => true`?

I should‚Äôve been more clear in my original description, but yes, this is possible today via custom transformations:

```rb
class AriaHiddenAttribute < InlineSvg::CustomTransformation
  def transform(doc)
    doc = Nokogiri::XML::Document.parse(doc.to_html)
    svg = doc.at_css "svg"
    svg["aria-hidden"] = value
    doc
  end
end


InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.add_custom_transformation(
    attribute: :aria_hidden,
    transform: AriaHiddenAttribute,
  )
end
```

This allows you to pass a `aria_hidden: true` option when using this `inline_svg` helper. Although each user can add this custom transformation today, I have found myself adding it to many project and using it quite often, so I thought it would be useful as a core feature.

> for custom attribute support, are there additional steps to take other than "aria-hidden" => true?

@seanpdoyle yes, see @tysongach's [example code](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/issues/72#issuecomment-335206874).

@elstgav thanks for the feedback, I appreciate you taking the time to write up this issue.

> I‚Äôm loading our SVG icon set outside of the assets folder, to avoid the asset pipeline and costly asset compilation. But inline_svg doesn‚Äôt recognize absolute file paths, since it relies on sprockets‚Äô .find_asset method.

Have you considered using the [boot-time asset caching](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#caching-all-assets-at-boot-time) configuration? This accepts any absolute paths you choose and pre-loads all SVG documents during the Rails boot process. The configuration would look something like this:

```ruby
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.asset_file = InlineSvg::CachedAssetFile.new(
    paths: [
      "/absolute/path/to",
      "/some/other/absolute/path/of/your/choosing"
    ],
    filters: /\.svg/
  )
end
```

Then you could either call `inline_svg` and pass the absolute path, or you could pass just a fragment:

```erb
<%= inline_svg "/absolute/path/to/file.svg" %>
<%= inline_svg "/absolute/path/to/file" %>
<%= inline_svg "file.svg" %>
<%= inline_svg "of/your/choosing/other-file" %>
```

> Can you add support for absolute file paths? I‚Äôm assuming it would require a few lines added to either AssetFile or FindsAssetPaths

I'll definitely keep this in mind for a future update. Alternatively, if you have the motivation and wanted to try adding this behavior yourself, I'd be happy to work with you on a pull request.

The problem is we‚Äôre using an icon library with thousands of SVGs; we‚Äôre only using a few of them so far, so I‚Äôm assuming boot-time caching the entire library would be overkill.

If more people are interested in absolute file paths I can open a PR, otherwise the patch I‚Äôm using works well enough for me now. Thanks for the plugin!

> The problem is we‚Äôre using an icon library with thousands of SVGs; we‚Äôre only using a few of them so far, so I‚Äôm assuming boot-time caching the entire library would be overkill.

It would be interesting to see what kind of penalty in terms of memory overhead and boot time increase you would pay for adding the entire icon library path and caching them on boot. But I understand your hesitation in this case.


> If more people are interested in absolute file paths I can open a PR, otherwise the patch I‚Äôm using works well enough for me now.

Thanks for offering to do that, I appreciate your feedback and any help you can spare with adding features in future.

Using this new feature, one might do something like this:

```ruby
class InMemorySVG
  SVGS = {
    marker: "<svg>something</svg>",
    other: "<svg>other</svg>"
  }

  def self.named(name)
    SVGS[name]    
  end
end

InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.asset_file(InMemorySVG)
end

# view
= inline_svg(:marker, class: "blue")
```

Is that the basic idea?

---

As an aside, here's an example of how to memoize inline SVGs to speedup rendering without using a custom loader. I wanted to render SVG map markers with different colors using CSS. Calling `inline_svg` repeatedly in a view was expensive, so I wrapped the method (in a presenter or helper):

```ruby
def svg_marker
  @svg_marker ||= inline_svg("marker.svg", class: "blue")
end
```

The benefit of the above code is that it loads the SVG from the file only once per request, which was fast enough for my case.

> Is that the basic idea?

@teeparham yes, that's the basic idea. Taking your example one step further I've been experimenting with having the custom asset file take a list of static asset directories (and filter patterns) that it uses to glob for SVGs, which are then pre-loaded into memory on application startup. That way *all* assets are cached and avoid filesystem reads. I may make this an optional part of the gem if it turns out to be useful.

> Calling inline_svg repeatedly in a view was expensive, so I wrapped the method (in a presenter or helper)

That's a nice example of memoizing the call to `inline_svg`. I've been profiling the code recently and plan to make some performance improvements soon such that even hundreds of thousands of calls per page should be super fast (not the case currently).

@neumayr thanks for submitting this feature request. 

I want to think very carefully before adding new built-in transformations. I'm trying hard to prevent the core of this gem becoming complicated and difficult to maintain. If it's easy to maintain then I can keep it updated and compatible with a wide range of Rails projects. 

That said, I have a few questions about the functionality of this transformation:

- How do we know which attributes are unwanted? Would this be configurable by the user?
- How many built-in unwanted style attributes would we have to consider?
- Would it be possible for the user to configure the transformation to remove additional attributes?

One way to help me make a decision is to create a [Custom Transformation](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#custom-transformations), demonstrating the intended behavior. If your custom transformation seems like it would be useful to many users then it would be an easier decision to accept it into the core.

If you're interested in writing a custom transformation then I'm happy to help you get it working. Check out the documentation and keep this issue updated with your progress.

@meowsus What happens when you use a third-party lib that does something different from what you're doing? You've now clobbered it by styling the base element. It does make sense to style base elements sometimes, but not with something as specific as dimensions. Some flexible defaults might make sense (for example `width:100%; height:auto;` for responsive images. If you look at ITCSS it does the bare minimum with the base classes. Just sets flexible, sensible defaults on top of normalisation. 

Actually, even your h1 example is something I avoid. h1-6 have semantic meaning (the importance of the header) but this should be decoupled from the styling as otherwise you bake in the way the header looks with what it means. This might make sense in simple documents, but often not in a complex webpage or application and not on a responsive site where often on mobile, sizes are not indicative of importance. 

It is also much easier to remove styles by removing a class than by overriding base styles - How can you remove a style on a base element?

There are numerous other arguments but I think these are the main ones.
I see your point. Especially regarding the third-party library.

I think the rule is that if you are normalising, resetting or setting
defaults, do it on the element (as long as they are genuinely defaults and
you don't end up overriding them everywhere) Otherwise functionality should
be added by classes. The classes should contain as few rules as possible
and you shouldn't be afraid to have many classes on an element.

`inline_svg` always tries to use Sprockets to dynamically find files. The Sprockets asset finder is pretty lenient, allowing you to leave off the file extension. If you disable Sprockets in production and instead opt to serve precompiled assets (as many people do, for performance reasons), then we fall back to a naive asset finder, which simply looks in the `#{Rails.root.join("public")}` directory for the exact filename. We could update the naive asset finder to append `.svg` if it's not present. The reason we don't raise an error when a file is not found is to mirror Rails' built-in image tag helpers, which will simply render the `` tag regardless if the file exists. You should see a HTML comment in your rendered page that tells you the SVG file could not be found.

Didn't know that, very interesting! I think it's indeed a good idea to mirror the image_tag helpers. Maybe we could try clarifying the error message:

``` ruby
if filename.ends_with? '.svg'
  "<svg><!-- SVG file not found: '#{filename}' --></svg>"
else
  "<svg><!-- SVG file not found: '#{filename}' (Try adding '.svg' to your filename) --></svg>"
end
```

> Maybe we could try clarifying the error message

Good idea. We could add that hint if we're using the naive asset finder and not Sprockets.

> Why not simply put `.svg` extension when not present? @madeindjs the reason I chose to add the empty `` tag. I felt this would be more consistent and approachable to Rails developers. We added the extension "hint" as a convenience.

@Undistraction could this be done with a [custom transformation](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#custom-transformations)? 

I'm reluctant to build more specific transformations into the library because it increases the maintenance overhead: For example, when illustrator changes the way it creates its XML markup output, `inline_svg` would have to follow suit and support both old and new versions.

  <defs>
    <style>
      .cls-1 {
        fill: #343434;
      }
    </style>
  </defs>
  <title>dotted_line</title>
  <path class="cls-1" d="M0,81a1,‚Ä¶ 1ba" />
</svg>
```

I don't think it would need to do anything Illustrator-specific - just remove styles added within the `<defs>` tag.

@Undistraction here's a custom transformation that will strip the style tag from your document:

``` ruby
class StripIllustratorStyles < InlineSvg::CustomTransformation
  def transform(doc)
    doc = Nokogiri::XML::Document.parse(doc.to_html)
    doc.at_css('svg defs style').remove
    doc
  end
end
```

You can load it in an initializer like so:

``` ruby
# config/initializers/inline_svg.rb
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.add_custom_transformation(attribute: :strip_styles, transform: StripIllustratorStyles)
end
```

And use it like this:

``` erb
<%= inline_svg('test.svg', strip_styles: true) %>
```

You can see all of that in action in this [test app](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg_test_app/commit/b68c589aca63d97bf66686e111cdf7311990bb76).

Actually, thinking about it a bit more. SHA1 is going to be unsuitable for an ID because it can generate garbage like this:

```
irb(main):007:0> OpenSSL::Digest::SHA1.digest("some-value")
=> "\xC1\xB2B\x94\xF0\x0E(\x16\x05\xF9\xDDj)\x86\x12\xE3\x06\x00b\xB4"
```

I don't think we want _that_ as an ID. Might have to switch to a random alpha/numeric generator.
Worked around the SHA1 byte-garbage problem by hexencoding the bytes, converting to a base16 fixnum and then working back to base36 to get a-zA-Z0-9. Should be fine.

> Is it possible add a transformation without any associated attribute?

@andrewaguiar No, sorry. It's not possible, but I'm open to changing the gem to accommodate "static" custom transformations.

As a workaround I suggest rewriting your transformation like this:

``` ruby
class SetFocusableTransform < InlineSvg::CustomTransformation
  def transform(doc)
    svg = doc.at_css('svg')
    svg['focusable'] = !!value.to_s
    doc
  end
end
```

Configure it like this:

``` ruby
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.add_custom_transformation(attribute: :focusable, transform: SetFocusableToFalseTransform)
end
```

And use it like this:

``` ruby
inline_svg('some-document.svg', focusable: true)
inline_svg('some-document.svg', focusable: false)
```

@ASnow thanks for the PR. Could you give me some details about why you made this change?

Do you want to allow both filenames _and_ IO objects? 

If you _only_ want to allow IO objects, without doing any filename resolution, then you could do this in your rails app:

``` ruby

#./lib/noop_asset_finder.rb
class NoopAssetFinder

  # custom asset finder that simply returns IO objects, rather than attempting to look up their path
  def self.find_asset(filename)
    if filename.is_a?(IO)
      filename
    end
  end
end

#./config/initializers/inline_svg.rb
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.asset_finder = NoopAssetFinder
end

```

> Also if the SVG file itself already has a title, but I pass a new title in through the options hash, I'd like it to overwrite the existing title in the SVG file, rather than adding an extra title to the element.

This sounds like a bug. I'll add a separate issue and get that fixed.

As for the accessibility attributes, it probably make sense to build in the most common ones, but I can't commit to doing them immediately. 

If you're keen to add specific attributes, it's relatively easy to extend the behavior of inline_svg by adding [custom transformations](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#custom-transformations).

For example, to add the `role="img"` attribute you could write a custom transformation like this:

``` ruby

# .role_attribute.rb
class RoleAttribute < InlineSvg::CustomTransformation
  def transform(doc)
    if value
      doc = Nokogiri::XML::Document.parse(doc.to_html)
      svg = doc.at_css 'svg'
      svg['role'] = "img"
    end
    doc
  end
end

# in an initializer, like ./config/initializers/inline_svg.rb
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.add_custom_transformation(attribute: :role, transform: RoleAttribute)
end


# in your view...
inline_svg('my_svg.svg', role: true)
```

Custom transformations could also be used to add any of the other accessibility tags that you need in the interim.

@coneybeare, thanks for the detailed description of this issue and the proposed options :+1: 

I'm reluctant to add this behavior to the gem for a number of reasons:
- I'm keen to make the core functionality of the gem simple (handle fewer special cases)
- If we choose one of a possible three solutions, it's entirely likely that people will request support for the other two
- It's possible to extend the document transformation pipeline and achieve any one of your suggested solutions by writing a [custom transformation](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg#custom-transformations)

As a less automated workaround, one could completely remove the `<style>` tags from an SVG document and supply an external stylesheet to target and style each document's classes separately.

> Is it uncommon for there to be multiple svgs on the same page?

I think the usage of SVGs on the web, especially in embedded form, is relatively limited (compared to images and pure CSS). 

This gem is, in part, a response to finding it difficult to use SVGs in the real world. The original use-case was to have many of the same SVG displayed on a page, and styled differently (colors, sizes etc.) with external CSS, hence the need to embed and then add classes to the root-level document. I usually lean towards stripping out as much presentation information as possible, and doing all coloring, sizing etc. in external CSS. This gives the maximum flexibility.

Of course, if you're producing SVG documents for standalone use, then I can understand the desire to have embedded style information.

Just a sidetone: when inlining SVG's you are not benefiting from browser caching of that file. So by inlining you are saving 1 request but you are increasing the file size of your html document...

> I have come across a bug which is not entirely `inline_svg`s fault, but needs to be handled in the gem.
> 
> When you have two embedded svgs on the same page, the `style` tags that are contained in each svg can conflict... often because the same designer used the same layer names or styles in the original document. There are not namespaces per document inlined svg, and no natural separation as when letting the browser load from file, so when embedding multiple files in the page, the style tag of the second svg tag will effect the first.
> 
> For example, here are two style tags which are both valid in their own documents, but make a problem when embedded on the same page
> 
> ```
> <style type="text/css">.st0{fill:#F6B62E;} .st1{display:none;fill:#181818;} .st2{fill:#181818;}</style>
> <style type="text/css">.st0{fill:#181818;} .st1{fill:#F6B62E;}</style>
> ```
> 
> [Here](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/files/94954/inline_svg_bug.zip) is a sample project showing the issue.
> 
> Possible solution approaches:
> 
> 1. Rewrite the style tag when embedding to use the HTML5 [scoped attribute](http://www.w3.org/TR/html-markup/style.html#style.attrs.scoped): `style scoped='true'...`
> 2. Rewrite the style tag to prepend a class that has a unique id, one you also assign to the containing .svg: `.deadbeef. st0{...`
> 3. Replace all classes and ids in the svgs with a string that prepends them with a certain unique val: : `.deadbeef_st0{...` and `path class=`.deadbeef_st0`
> 
> Unfortunately, 1 seems to be a dead end due to [lack of browser support](http://caniuse.com/#search=scoped). 3 seems safest, but requires more editing of the file, and more text insertion.
> 
> 2 seems like a good balance, only adding a unique val in a few places: the svg's class tag, and the prepended in the individual styles within the style tag. The `path` and `g` elements would not need manipulation.
> 
> Thoughts?

If you are generating millions (i am not kidding) of inline svg images with associated colliding style blocks, to create unique styles for all of them would probably cripple the browser. Also WHY would they deprecate the scoped=true attribute. Just why???

@smellyshovel I think the problem with your first SVG is that the `path` element explicitly sets a `fill` attribute, which sets the color of the element:

```
 <path fill="#000000" 
```

This means that your original CSS was lower precedent (less specific) than the existing `fill` attribute on the element and so the browser prioritized the `#000000` value. When you added the `svg > path` selector, your CSS rule was specific enough to override the `fill` attribute.

The reason your second SVG behaves the way you expect is because you no longer have the `fill` attribute on the `path` elements.
