@dylanfareed seems like I made a [bad assumption here](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/blob/master/lib/inline_svg/railtie.rb#L15) (that `app.assets` would always be a working Sprockets instance).

 If I'm reading that change correctly, it looks like we might be able to fall back to the [`Sprockets::Rails::Helper#resolve_asset_path`](https://github.com/rails/sprockets-rails/blob/93a45b1c463a063ec7cf4d160107b67aa3db7a1a/lib/sprockets/rails/helper.rb#L74) method when `config.assets.compile = false`.

The asset finder in `InlineSvg` is also configurable, you just need to pass it an object that responds to `find_asset` and returns a file-like object that responds to `pathname`:

For example, to implement a really naive asset finder that only looks for assets in the `./public/images/` directory, you could do this in an initializer:

``` ruby
class NaiveAssetFinder
  def self.find_asset(filename)
    new(filename)
  end

  attr_accessor :pathname

  def initialize(filename)
    @pathname = "#{Rails.root.join('public', 'images', filename)}"
  end
end

InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.asset_finder = NaiveAssetFinder
end
```

In the next few days I'll try to make the default a little more resilient to this Sprockets change.

Experimented with Sprockets v3.0.0.beta2 today. When `config.assets.compile = false` there is very little chance of getting a properly configured `Sprockets` instance. Assets are now being served as static files from the `public/assets/` directory and they could even be on a CDN or other remote host. There is no guarantee that we can get access to them.

Changing the default `config.after_initialize` in the railtie to `config.asset_finder = app.config.assets` prevents things from exploding, but we also won't be able to resolve asset paths when `config.assets.compile = false`.

To accommodate this scenario we might be able to provide a configurable asset finder to replace Sprockets, which behaves a little like [my previous example](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/issues/25#issuecomment-148220993), except it uses the built-in Rails `asset_path` helpers to obtain the correct pathname. People choosing this option could configure the library like so:

``` ruby
InlineSvg.configure do |config|
  config.asset_finder = InlineSvg::StaticAssetFinder
end
```
FYI, Sprockets-rails 3.0 has been released for 5 days now so anyone who upgrades will be unable to compile in production.

I was able to determine that the SVG tag must include the line: "xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"

@l3iodeez that's really interesting. The [w3 spec](http://www.w3.org/TR/xlink/#att-method) does include documentation for this requirement, but it's very easy to miss:

> As dictated by [XML Names], the use of XLink elements and attributes requires declaration of the XLink namespace. For example, the following declaration would make the prefix xlink available within the myElement element to represent the XLink namespace:

``` xml
<myElement
  xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
  ...
</myElement>
```

Hi @l3iodeez, unfortunately `inline_svg` only currently works with local assets accessible via `Sprockets`. 

I can't think of a quick way to implement this feature currently, so I'll need to give it some thought. Do you have any suggestions for how this could work _and_ perform well (I would guess we should cache remote files and transforms somehow)? I've been considering a client-side counterpart library that could do remote transforms and embeds.

I agree that the SVGs would need to be locally cached for performance reasons. The rationale for doing this is so that my users can upload the images through a form instead of having include them in the repo, since Im using Heroku and it doesn't allow the saving of files directly to the server.

I don't think caching on the server side would work very well in this case (user uploads or dynamic content), especially given the restrictions on file system access with Heroku. 

The more I think about it, the more a client-side solution seems correct. Does your application have any restriction on Javascript compatibility or hard requirement for HTML fallback?

For the case where JavaScript is unacceptable, perhaps we could consider storing the transformed SVGs in a database.
Javascript is required for my app, so caching the SVGs client side would work, though I have to admit I don't really know how you would implement this.

There are three possible solutions I'm weighing:
1. Duplicate much of the server-side transformation logic into some companion Javascript code, which would be responsible for getting the remote SVG from the client's browser and doing the specified transformation client-side. The results could be cached using local storage, or similar.
2. Expose a rails server endpoint (perhaps via an engine), which would do the transformations and caching on behalf of the client-side Javascript. In this scenario, the Javascript would still be responsible for fetching the SVG from the remote URL, but could then pass the SVG to the rails server for transformation.
3. Keep all fetching and transforming on the server-side, but perform the work out-of-band of the page request/response cycle (some kind of queuing), then allow the client-side to poll the server for the file and receive it once the fetching/transforming is done.

There are benefits and drawbacks to each approach, so I want to think it through carefully before committing to one direction.
It seems like the first option would be the simplest to implement, but I have to admit I don't really know how the other two would work.

Agreed. I'm going to start on option 1 this week. Not sure if it's going to be a separate library or bundled as part of this gem. 

The changes to this gem would involve detecting the presence of a URI scheme in place of a filename and then inserting the transformations into a DOM element (probably as data attributes) for the JavaScript to use for the transformations.

@pineapple-thief thanks for the suggestion. My [first attempt at the Size transformation](https://github.com/jamesmartin/inline_svg/commit/03452ed037a59a39a14d966a6cc24a56041743ff#diff-5087a0c1014da75b9795feb78a7e4f8eR12) used the "5x5" notation, inspired by the [Rails `image_tag`](http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionView/Helpers/AssetTagHelper.html#method-i-image_tag)  helper syntax. This is fine for HTML img tags because the [HTML specification](http://www.w3.org/TR/html-markup/img.html#img.attrs.height) assumes height and width attributes are always supplied as CSS pixels.

However, the notation is more complicated for SVG because the [specification requires height and width units to be specified as a `length` type](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/types.html#DataTypeLength), which could be something like "px" or "em" or "%". I chose the `*` ‚Äî multiplication ‚Äî delimiter, which doesn't appear in any of the SVG `length` units.

For example, imagine this hypothetical scenario: `inline_svg('some.svg', size: '12pxx16px')`. This is pretty hard to read as a human. I find it much easier to read this: `inline_svg('some.svg', size: '12px*16px')`. 

What do you think?

Oh, it makes sense now, right. But what about id and data options? Those
could be helpful.

That may be correct since, in any synctex enabled viewer
If you have a .pdf and a .synctex(.gz) then on triggering inverse search it expects to open in the configured editor the samename.tex so if its not in the same directory it may start blank.
This can be affected by configuration , relative vs absolute paths, synctex engine version and viewer embedment's. so to test you need all 3 files from the same compile in the same test folder .

OK, my bad. It seems I had not enough inotify watches. I did the following and it fixed my problem:
```
echo "fs.inotify.max_user_watches=204800" | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.d/90-override.conf
```

> Do you mean the hasFocus helper? If so, I'm sorry ‚Äì seeing the same code repeated six times was screaming at me to make it a meaningful helper function, for obvious maintainability reasons.

I noticed how the config part was moved to package.json as well. But not a problem üòÑ

My pleasure! :D Thank you for taking the time to review!

> I noticed how the config part was moved to package.json as well. But not a problem

That's the canonical and recommended way of defining package-settings these days. `package.json` was the first place I went to add/edit settings, and I anticipate other users would do the same.

Early versions of Atom required authors to use JavaScript/CoffeeScript to define package settings (the same as you've been using), but a "formal" way to do this was then introduced. This has been the norm for quite some time: relocating the config was less about "refactoring" and more about "modernisation".

I probably should have mentioned that in the PR, but it appears to have slipped my memory. =) Sorry if this came across too pushy.

Eps files generated by other methods like matlab performs well, and inserting a pdf file as an image works too, so the problem must be in the conversion from pdf to eps. Practice proves that my guess is correct, and here's my solution:

when saving as a pdf to a eps file, click the settings button

Hi, @AustenLamacraft. Can you clarify what kinds of errors you're referring to? You said:

> This doesn't happen with a short document without errors, but I don't know whether it's down to the errors or the length.

But there's no mention of any errors before that. 

In any case, this package watches the PDF file it's displaying and reloads it if there are any changes. So, if the PDF file that's being generated is changing (e.g. the process that's generating it is incrementally building it, thus changing it) -- then it will be reloaded. That's expected behavior. Could you perhaps clarify what you expected to see instead?

PDFs are indeed created "incrementally" by latexmk (the tool typically used by latex builders). So, yes, this is expected behavior. I think you should explore latexmk options to create an intermediate file before pushing a final PDF to the output.

You are correct that this is the "expected" behavior, since LaTeX compilation involves multiple passes, and at each pass the pdf is changed. However, especially with long documents (and not so long ones, actually, depending on the hardware) where the load time is noticeable, this behavior is very annoying. I used `pdf-view` for a while and currently I'm not using it anymore precisely for this reason. 

Thus, while the current behavior is technically correct, I think something better can be achieved. Here is an idea. A settings switch to disable the automatic reload itself would do the trick. Latex Atom plugins (`latextools` at least, which is the one I use) by themselves already open the resulting pdf on a "viewer" when the pdf is ready. E.g. if the selected viewer is `pdf-view` instead of an external program, and no pdf is currently open, a new tab is open with the pdf file displayed in it. I suppose this happens also when the tab is already opened, and by the way, this is currently causing yet another useless reload, because `pdf-view` reloads the pdf when it changes and then is asked to reload it again. This means that, by giving the option of disabling the auto reload, the reload would happen only once, at the end, when the latex plugin requests it. 

I think this is feasible and easy. What do you think?

Thanks for sharing your thoughts, @nicola-gigante 

> I think this is feasible and easy. What do you think?

I don't have time to work on that myself, but if you'd like to give it a try -- I'd be happy to review a pull request.

> Latex Atom plugins (latextools at least, which is the one I use) by themselves already open the resulting pdf on a "viewer" when the pdf is ready. E.g. if the selected viewer is pdf-view instead of an external program, and no pdf is currently open, a new tab is open with the pdf file displayed in it. I suppose this happens also when the tab is already opened, and by the way, this is currently causing yet another useless reload, because pdf-view reloads the pdf when it changes and then is asked to reload it again. This means that, by giving the option of disabling the auto reload, the reload would happen only once, at the end, when the latex plugin requests it.

From what I can see they (both [`latextools`](https://github.com/msiniscalchi/atom-latextools) and [`latex`](https://github.com/thomasjo/atom-latex)) always call `atom.workspace.open` with the pdf file, which works as expected when the file is not already open. But if the pdf is already open in some other tab, from what I can understand, `atom.workspace.open` doesn't give any signal to `pdf-view` package and the pdf is not updated if auto reload is turned off.

To resolve this issue properly, I think, pdf-view needs to provide an API to update pdf. And the latex packages need to call that it the pdf is already open and run foreardSync once the pdf is updated to properly synchronise everything.

Suggestions?

> To resolve this issue properly, I think, pdf-view needs to provide an API to update pdf. And the latex packages need to call that it the pdf is already open and run foreardSync once the pdf is updated to properly synchronise everything.

Alternatively, we can maybe also listen to `atom.workspace.onDidOpen` and treat that as signal that someone wants to open an updated pdf, when auto reload is off.

Thanks for thinking of other approaches, @nisargjhaveri :bow: If you'd like to try and implement one of those approaches and see if it solves the problem for those other plugins -- I'd be happy to review the PR!

       I came across the same issue (the 'blinking' of the `pdf-view` when compiling using latex). As it was mentioned above, it is an expected behavior that `pdf-view` updates the pdf when compiling. However, it is annoying, and from user perspective, it is not necessary to show  the result of every step of the compilation. I understand that this is not the issue of `pdf-view` nor the latex compiler since they do both their job. @recluze  mentioned using a temporary file to store the intermediate changes of the pdf before finally updating the pdf file. I think it is a reasonable solution.

I read [this update](https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/pull/192) where `auto-reload on update` option is added. However, when unchecked, no update to pdf is done, which is the job. I do want to see the final changes of the pdf.

I don't know if I missed something in the conversation, but it would be better if `pdf-view` updates the pdf only when the compilation is done and not after each intermediate step (since latex does many updates).

I use [latex package](https://github.com/thomasjo/atom-latex) for compilation.

Any suggestions on how to fix this (probably changing the configuration of atom, latex, pdf-view, ... )?
Thanks

Disable "auto-reload on update" and set `latex` to open file using `pdf-view` when compilation is done.

I used the two packages with this config for some time, and it worked perfectly. Unless something is changed recently. I no longer use this as much. 

#204 enabled this scenario.

Thanks! it did the trick!
Disabling `autod-reload on update` and setting `latex` opener to `pdf-view` reload ONCE the pdf at the end of the compilation AND highlights the  modified part using a red graded ball instead of a red rectangle.

@hasantahir Sorry for not responding to your question sooner. I'm afraid I can't help you there -- I'm not familiar with *TeX setups and the synctex feature was added by a contributor to this package. If someone else watching this repository can help you debug -- that would be great. If you've already figured out things -- please post some notes for other folks who might run into the same problem. Thanks!

The synctex feature, unfortunately, depends on the `synctex` binary provided by TeXLive, but not provided by MiKTeX. Synctex usually works with most synctex-aware PDF viewers because they tend to contain a linked version of the [synctex library](http://itexmac.sourceforge.net/SyncTeX.html). The only way I'm aware of to get things working on MiKTeX is to install TeXLive and copy the `synctex.exe` file somewhere then uninstall TeXLive (`synctex.exe` may have other dependencies; I can't check atm).

I see the status bar just fine on Atom 1.9.9 when I open a PDF. Perhaps some of your other packages are causing problems? Can you reproduce the problem with only pdf-view installed (and no other packages)? Does it happen for every PDF or only some? 

Also, you can jump to a page using a command: "Pdf View: Go To Page" from the command palette.

Ok, I took a look at the synctex implementation and there's a slight problem. I assumed that synctex was based on links, but it is actually a program which takes raw coordinates as input. This makes the implementation for lilypond support quite different from the synctex support.

What lilypond support would need to do is intercept clicks on links, and `exec` the correct script if the link is a special lilypond link.

I spent some time trying to write a pdf-viewer plugin for atom with support for annotations (e.g. links). But working with pdf.js was pretty horrible, since it predates javescript modules and e.g. uses a custom, make-file based module system. I did not manage to successfully display pdfs in atom with annotation support. At some point I [embedded the default pdfjs viewer in an iframe](https://github.com/AljoschaMeyer/atom-pdfjs). That gives you support for links (and e.g. the ability to select text). But integrating that with atom (keyboard shortcuts via the atom options, theming etc.) might be more effort than using the pdf-js api for building a suitable viewer plugin. Still, for quick-and-dirty point-and-click support, this might be the way to go.

(Sorry, should've checked before commenting, but I couldn't actually reproduce issue 137 using the test file provided by Haydnspass. Since the zoom issue I was running into was with embedded figures, I'll move my efforts here instead.)

I've traced the bug to [this line](https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/blob/c6078d9ef490221f7220425e30504adbf36c69b2/lib/pdf-editor-view.js#L384) in `pdf-editor-view.js`. On a pixel-doubled / "retina" screen, that line is supposed to double the size / resolution of the rendered image. However the change in scaling doesn't apply to certain embedded figures (possibly those that involve running the `beginGroup`‚Äì`endGroup` pair in pdf.js) because they seem to be drawn based on `context._transformMatrix`, which is only defined in pdf.js and thus unaffected by the default `scale` method. These figures end up being drawn at the 1x coordinates, hence appearing small and displaced.

It's only after the initial invocation of `context.scale` that pdf.js initializes the context properly and overwrites the `scale` method with `ctxScale`, which does interact with `_transformMatrix`. On subsequent renders the call `context.scale(2,2)` doubles the entries of `context._transformMatrix` each time, and so the figures get drawn at 2x, 4x, 8x, etc.

Note that ovirtanen's screenshot here and fabianp's on the other issue was taken on a retina display, while jiaweiw's wasn't.

Edit: Just pushed a workaround.

Thanks for submitting a PR! I'd like to get a better understanding of 1) what problem you're observing (and try to reproduce it), and 2) how this change fixes the problem. For 1), please see my comment in https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/issues/117#issuecomment-183679640. For 2), I'd be interested to hear more about that here. Being as clear and as precise as possible would be helpful.

When a pdf file is updated, `updatePDF` starts with removing the current canvases, and only then tries to open the updated file. If the new file is empty or only partially build, `PDFJS.getDocument` throws an error, which is catched with `finishUpdate`. Result: the view is empty, and position and zoom-level are reset.

This can be solved by only removing the current canvases if the pdf is read succesfully by `pdf.js`. This ensures that a pdf stays visible when it is rebuild, and keeps it position.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Make a copy of a pdf file (we'll call them `original.pdf` and `copy.pdf`)
2. Open `copy.pdf` in atom, and scroll down.
3. Then simulate an external tool that (slowly) rebuilds the pdf
   1. `dd if=original.pdf of=copy.pdf bs=1k count=0`
   2. `dd if=original.pdf of=copy.pdf bs=1k count=10`
   3. ...

The pdf-view in atom is empty during step 3. When `copy.pdf` is completely rebuild, it reappears, but the position and zoom-level is reset.

Building a pdf with e.g. latex can take some time. It's annoying that you can't see the pdf during the build, and that the position is lost when it's back.

``` cs
class PaneResizeHandleElement extends HTMLElement

  # ...

  resizePane: ({clientX, clientY, which}) ->
    return @resizeStopped() unless which is 1
    return @resizeStopped() unless @previousSibling? and @nextSibling?

    if @isHorizontal
      totalWidth = @previousSibling.clientWidth + @nextSibling.clientWidth
      #get the left and right width after move the resize view
      leftWidth = clientX - @previousSibling.getBoundingClientRect().left
      leftWidth = @fixInRange(leftWidth, 0, totalWidth)
      rightWidth = totalWidth - leftWidth
      # set the flex grow by the ratio of left width and right width
      # to change pane width
      @setFlexGrow(leftWidth, rightWidth)
    else
      totalHeight = @previousSibling.clientHeight + @nextSibling.clientHeight
      topHeight = clientY - @previousSibling.getBoundingClientRect().top
      topHeight = @fixInRange(topHeight, 0, totalHeight)
      bottomHeight = totalHeight - topHeight
      @setFlexGrow(topHeight, bottomHeight)

  resizeStopped: ->
    document.removeEventListener 'mousemove', @resizePane
    document.removeEventListener 'mouseup', @resizeStopped
```

Hey @nsaje -- thanks for the pull request. I'm a bit confused about how all of this is supposed to work. It seems that half of the implementation is here and half is in your fork of the atom-latex package (not even in the atom-latex package itself).

So, if someone installs just pdf-view, they can't really use this, even if half of the functionality is here. That doesn't sound right to me and it wouldn't really close #107 in my opinion. You shouldn't need to install other packages to use this in pdf-view. And again, it seems that the other half is only in your fork for atom-latex, not in the package itself. 

Do you think it would be possible to make forward sync within this package alone?

Sorry about it being in my fork only - I didn't want to push a PR to atom-latex that uses atom-pdf-view's functionality that doesn't exist yet.

As to why the functionality is split in two; it's because this is how synctex support is usually handled. The PDF viewer exposes the syncing functionality, but it is the editor's job to initiate the sync. This is how both atom-latex and atom-latextools handle forward syncing with other PDF viewers; they provide a command/keybinding that then syncs the editor's position to the PDF.

The way I see it atom-pdf-view should be responsible for what happens when a user has the PDF focused. What happens when the user is editing latex should be handled by latex plugins.

But this is just my opinion and if you disagree, I'll be happy to modify the PR and include for example a keybinding that, when editing a latex file, will trigger a forward sync to PDF (which might clash with latex packages' functionality), or whichever way you want it done. :smile:

Thanks for explaining, @nsaje -- I appreciate that and I see your point.

I think I'd still like to see this implemented completely in pdf-view. I guess it comes down to this question: would it be possible and would it be useful to have this functionality even if you don't have an additional latex package installed? I think the answer to both of those questions in "yes". I shouldn't need to install a package for compiling latex documents (which is what atom-latex is for) in order to get a sync behavior between the source file and the PDF (that would be useful even if I'm not re-compiling the PDF). I'd expect that sync to work even without such a package or with any other latex package that comes along in the future.

That said, I think there's no downside in having this merged so that you could perhaps open a pull request to update atom-latex as well and move forward with this. We can always revisit the have-everything-in-pdfview idea later.

Thanks again for explaining and for your work :bow: :zap:

I was testing on a different machine today, where synctex is NOT on the path and `synctexPath` is therefore set. On this system, paths with spaces work fine as `execFile` automatically takes care of quoting. For systems where `synctexPath` is not set, `exec` is used instead with a regular string. Is it possible to call a program that is on the path via `execFile` which is generally much safer?

So setting the path explicitly is a good workaround for now.

Perhaps one should think about adding `\s*` at the beginning and the end of the line to get more robust or just call `trim()` before evalutating the regular expression.

I could cherry-pick that commit, but I think it's better if we do this through a new PR. Before we do that, I'm wondering if you could clarify one thing:

> The regular expression is not valid if there is a CR at the end of the line and there m is null.

If there is a CR at the end of that line, wouldn't that still be matched by the `(.*)` in the regex? A `.` matches anything, right? So `line.match /^([a-zA-Z]*):(.*)$/` should match any line beginning with letters and a colon afterwards because `(.*)` will match anything until the end of the line. I definitely might be wrong, I normally am when regexes are involved. :smile: 

Still, the line number would not be correct because it would contain a CR at the end, which I think is what @autc04 was referring to.

My reasoning was, that my package creates PDF's and your package displays them. I do not think, that markdown-themeable-pdf should display them, that was not the aim and the focus would be lost.

As I said, it was just an idea. ;) If there would be a command like `atomPdfView.show(path);`, it would be easy to trigger it from another package.

> If there would be a command like atomPdfView.show(path);, it would be easy to trigger it from another package.

There already is such a command, but not in pdf-view -- it's a general command for all files:

```
atom.workspace.open("path/to/file.pdf")
```

Atom then opens the file with the correct "opener" for that file type. If you have pdf-view installed and a the file ends with `.pdf`, then [pdf-view's opener is triggered](https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/blob/44a74abc5317041a017f29fb1b205efe0d77562d/lib/pdf-editor.coffee#L6).

I had some time today to create a (negative) repro.
It uses the following tex file:

> \documentclass{article}
> \usepackage{lipsum}
> \begin{document}
> \lipsum[1-100]
> \end{document}

First I turned it into a pdf (pdflatex repro.tex) and created a python script that touched it periodically while it was open in atom.io, but atom would not reload it (I do not know how the reload mechanism works).
Instead, I rewrote the python script to recreate the pdf every time. Here is the python script

> #usage example: python repro.py repro.tex 50 2
> import sys,subprocess,time,shutil
> file = sys.argv[1]; count = int(sys.argv[2]); interv = int(sys.argv[3]);
> for i in range(count):
>   print '{}/{}{}'.format(i+1, count, '\n' if i%24==0 else ''),
>   sys.stdout.flush()
>   pop = subprocess.Popen(["pdflatex", 'repro.tex'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
>   pop.wait()
>   time.sleep(interv)

While I ran the script I observed visible reloading in atom.io. The memory of atom helper went up and down, but it did not increase in general. Hence, I conclude that the out of memory problem is not due to pdf-view, but due to atom.io, it could probably be related to this: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1827

@timjb Thanks for taking the time to open this PR and also for the write-up in https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/issues/64#issuecomment-123486891. :zap: :zap: 

I think I understand what you're describing, and I guess it's possible this happens. I still wish I could reproduce this, though. Have you been able to reliably reproduce the problem with a specific latex document and specific changes made to the document? 

Regardless of that, I think we can give this a try. :+1: Before we do, I wanted to run one other idea by you.

Currently, the `debounce` call in `onFileChangeCallback` is set to wait 100ms for any other calls to that callback before invoking `updatePdf`. It seems to me that we might increase that wait period (e.g. to 1s) to make this problem appear less frequently. If a change happens for a file and then no other changes happen for 100ms -- then the file will be updated in pdf-view. But if a change happens soon after those 100 ms pass and while the file is being updated -- then the problem surfaces, right? So, we could wait for a bit longer for changes to happen. When combined with your fix in this PR, this would prevent the file from being re-updated frequently, e.g. if a file changes 10 times with 105ms between two changes then the file would be re-rendered 10 times, right? But if we increase the wait period to 500-100s, then only one render would happen, which might be a better experience.

What do you think?

I can reproduce the problem quite reliably with [membrane-surface.tex](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/1554469/membrane-surface.tex). Compile the file with `pdflatex membrane-surface.tex`, open `membrane-surface.pdf` in pdf-view and the recompile the file. This gives me a black pane in >90% of runs.

This is why this file exposes the bug: The LaTeX drawing at the beginning of the document takes a long time to compile and triggers a rerendering immediately after LaTeX has finished this part of the document. Rendering the document takes a long time, again because of that drawing. The final few paragraphs of text are compiled relatively fast and LaTeX finishes compiling before rerendering has finished.

It seems like a good idea to increase the debounce timeout. But one second is a bit too long in my opinion. Some users might be compiling a simple LaTeX file which takes only about half a second to compile. I think it would be bad user experience to make them wait for 1.5 seconds instead of 0.5 seconds to see the changes to the document.

> e.g. if a file changes 10 times with 105ms between two changes then the file would be re-rendered 10 times, right?

Only if rendering takes < 105ms. If it takes longer, the file will be rerendered fewer times. One of my documents currently takes 300ms to render.

Another idea: One could use the file size heurestic to guess when LaTeX (or another program) has finished compiling: it has finished when the file size of the PDF is roughly the same as after the last successful rendering. Of course the file size can change, for example when the user adds an image to the document. This might be combined with a flexible debounce timeout: If the file is still smaller than after the last rerender, then a larger timespan without change is needed to trigger a render than when the file size roughly matches the full size after the last rerendering.

One last idea: The "right" debounce timeout could be dynamically determined on a per-document basis. One could remember how long the longest pause between two file changes was where rendering wasn't successful after the first change.

Finally, it might not be so bad to rerender often: It isn't apparent from the user interface that pdf-view tries to rerender the document multiple times while it's being updated. All the user sees is a black pane, no flickering etc.

> Finally, it might not be so bad to rerender often: It isn't apparent from the user interface that pdf-view tries to rerender the document multiple times while it's being updated. All the user sees is a black pane, no flickering etc.

That sounds great. I think you're right -- let's merge this and see if anyone sees any problems and we can come back to these ideas then.

Thanks again for fixing this :heart: :heart:

I've got a similar problem. I'm using pdf-view to see the compiled PDF beside the LaTeX source in Atom. Randomly, after compiling the LaTeX file, pdf-view fails to reload the PDF.

The issue seems to be that pdflatex writes the PDF continuously as it is compiling. (Some PDF viewers don't handle this well: for example, when you view a PDF in Mac OS X's Preview, and you switch to the window with the PDF file while regenerating that file with pdflatex, Preview crashes.) After looking at the code of pdf-view, I've got an idea of what's probably going on:
1. I start rebuilding my document: `pdflatey mydocument.tex`
2. pdflatex begins writing `mydocument.pdf`
3. atom-view detects the file change and begins reloading and rerendering the document
4. pdflatex finishes compiling
5. atom-view finishes rerendering the document, which results in a blank screen, because the version it tried to render wasn't a correct PDF file

The problem seems to be that file changes that occur while atom-view is refreshing do not trigger a new refresh.

@frxstrem This workaround may help in the meantime: This script builds the PDF file in a separate directory and moves the finished PDF into place afterwards (if there wasn't an error).

``` sh
#!/bin/sh

set -e
pdflatex -output-directory output mydocument.tex
cp output/mydocument.pdf .
```

I got the same error message; what helped me was to change line 26 in the files pdf.js and pdf.worker.js by escaping the forward slashes in the `PDFJS.build` string, e.g. changing `/home` to `\/home`.

Can anyone who has this working paste the `PDFJS.build` line from these files?
- `~/.atom/packages/pdf-view/node_modules/pdf.js/build/pdf.js`
- `~/.atom/packages/pdf-view/node_modules/pdf.js/build/pdf.worker.js`
- `~/.atom/packages/pdf-view/node_modules/pdf.js/build/generic/build/pdf.js`
- `~/.atom/packages/pdf-view/node_modules/pdf.js/build/generic/build/pdf.worker.js`

changing all these 4 from this

```
  25 PDFJS.version = '1.0.2';
  26 PDFJS.build = 'fatal: Not a git repository (or any parent up to mount point /home)Stopping at filesystem boundary (GIT_DISCOVERY_ACROSS_FILESYSTEM not set).
  27 ';
```

to this

```
  25 PDFJS.version = '1.0.2';
  26 PDFJS.build = 'lel';
  27 
```

fixed it :)

seems like the build string expand thingy uses the current git commit, but for some of us there is no git repo holding pdf.js so this fails...

https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/blob/master/make.js#L489

EDIT: added an issue on pdf.js: https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/issues/5920 and https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/issues/5921

they (reasonably) said that the git repo should be in place.

I haven't looked at the code yet, but I did try it out and seems to be working great. Noticed just a few minor issues:
1. the page indicator/selector in the status bar is not visible immediately after loading a PDF, but is shown after scrolling. (Currently, that indicator/selector is visible as soon as you open a PDF).  
2. for PDFs that have different-sized pages, jumping to a page might not land you on the top of the page (which would be expected behavior), but rather somewhere else if those pages haven't been loaded yet. I'm not sure if this can be fixed -- since pages are no longer loaded all at once, you don't know what the sizes of all pages before they are visible. 3. for PDFs that have different-sized pages, zooming and then scrolling to a page of different height causes jumpy behavior.

Also, could you try installing pdf-view locally, updating it to the latest version of pdf.js and see if that helps? Here's what you'd need to do:
1. Uninstall pdf-view: `apm uninstall pdf-view`
2. Clone this project: `git clone https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/`
3. `cd atom-pdf-view`
4. Edit the package.json file and change the version number for the [pdf.js reference](https://github.com/izuzak/atom-pdf-view/blob/b3372f51829cd3431280eb77c644a1348cc29ab9/package.json#L17). Currently, that version is 4834f1c28924b3322f00b8383ddb8478193be930, and the latest version of pdf.js is [d66314cfb3a07c70f8385dd58ad7d872591ac8f5](https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/commit/d66314cfb3a07c70f8385dd58ad7d872591ac8f5). So, use that version number instead. 
5. Build and install: `apm install`
6. Link the local version: `apm link`
7. Start Atom and see if anything changed with regard to the blurriness
8. Quit Atom
9. Unlink the local version: `apm unlink`

Thanks for investigating this, @Bengt! I won't have time to tackle this myself in the near future, but if you'd like to give it a try -- that would be awesome! :sparkles:

The text content that pdfjs returns is very fragmented - a single sentence, for example, can be divided into multiple objects depending on character size, fonts and other formatting attributes.

Apparently the way Mozilla deals with this is just creating div elements for each of the object, so that collectively the text layer still resembles the contents. While this would work for copying to Microsoft Word or TextEdit, it behaves abnormally in Atom as all text contents are aggregated into one single line, whitespaces and newlines mysteriously lost... [Mozilla's demo](http://mozilla.github.io/pdf.js/web/viewer.html) exhibits the same problem, and I'm still trying to find a solution.

So far I've only been able to get the text layer working. Copying any content from Atom to external text editor works with formatting preserved, but not within Atom if the destination is a TextEditor instance.

If needed, here's [link to my fork](https://github.com/lafickens/atom-pdf-view).

üëã @steeef: It's possible to entirely remove the dependency on Karabiner-Elements, but in my experience, doing so has always involved some UX compromises.

Back in 2018, https://github.com/pqrs-org/Karabiner-Elements/issues/545 led me to remove the dependency on Karabiner-Elements and implement everything with Hammerspoon, and I shipped that change in [jasonrudolph/keyboard v4.0.0](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/releases/tag/v4.0.0).

That worked, but I found the UX of that particular implementation to be inferior as described in #38. (Perhaps there's an alternative Hammerspoon-based implementation that would provide UX comparable to the Karabiner-Elements implementation, but I'm not aware of such an implementation.) So once https://github.com/pqrs-org/Karabiner-Elements/issues/545 was resolved, #38 reinstated the use of Karabiner-Elements.

The problems described in #40, #59, and #60 were also side effects of removing the dependency on Karabiner-Elements. https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/pull/61 resolved those issues by porting (S)uper (D)uper Mode from Hammerspoon to Karabiner-Elements.

With that in mind, I will likely postpone my personal upgrade to Big Sur until https://github.com/pqrs-org/Karabiner-DriverKit-VirtualHIDDevice is capable of supporting all the existing functionality in this repository.

I hope that helps.

üëã Hi @danielinfuse: If you fork the repository and change the code, then you could customize it to enter (S)uper (D)uper Mode with a single keystroke. You'll likely need to try your hands at a bit of Lua to make it work, but it should be do-able.

To get started, you could look at the code for [Markdown Mode](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/tree/3bee475a114f2e2697d536676d96f77bafb26b2e#markdown-mode), which is triggered with a single keystroke (<kbd>control</kbd> + <kbd>m</kbd>) here:

https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/blob/3bee475a114f2e2697d536676d96f77bafb26b2e/hammerspoon/markdown.lua#L106-L112

You could use a similar approach to change [`super.lua`](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/blob/v5.0.0/hammerspoon/super.lua) to trigger (S)uper (D)uper Mode with a single keystroke. It will be a bit of work, but it's do-able if you put your mind to it. üòÖ

Since I [personally prefer](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/tree/3bee475a114f2e2697d536676d96f77bafb26b2e#more-useful-for-me) using the <kbd>s</kbd> + <kbd>d</kbd> keys to trigger (S)uper (D)uper Mode, it's unlikely that I'll change this functionality, but I hope the pointer above is helpful.

@aantipov: Thanks for that clarification. That allowed me to successfully reproduce the issue.

Currently, (S)uper (D)uper Mode looks for specific English characters. For example:

https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/blob/2d2b159f071f7a0461874defd4ba966974aa72a8/hammerspoon/super.lua#L35-L37

When using an English keyboard, this works. When using a non-English keyboard, it doesn't work. Thanks for identifying this issue! :bow:

---

If anyone has some time to investigate a fix, I think this could be resolved by updating [`super.lua`](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/blob/2d2b159f071f7a0461874defd4ba966974aa72a8/hammerspoon/super.lua) to look at keycodes instead of characters. For example, the excerpt above would become something like this:

```lua
  local keyCode = event:getKeyCode()

  if keyCode == hs.keycodes.map['s'] then
```

You can see the related API docs at:

- https://www.hammerspoon.org/docs/hs.eventtap.event.html#getKeyCode
- https://www.hammerspoon.org/docs/hs.keycodes.html#map

There are a handful of places where `super.lua` currently uses `event:getCharacters()`, so all of those places will likely need to be updated to use keycodes instead.

This is likely resolved by #61, so I'm going to close this issue.

If you're still able to reproduce the problem using the latest code on the `master` branch, please let me know, and I'll re-open this issue. :bow:

@rfrank6023 I thought of one other debugging step that might help you: If you launch the `Karabiner-EventViewer` app, you can press keys on your keyboard, and it will show you what keys Karabiner observes. For example, on my Kinesis Freestyle 2 keyboard, when I press s+d+f+z, Karabiner sees all 4 keys. As a result, this enters super-duper mode and it gets converted to command+z, which then performs an undo operation. > On the German Keyboard the 'right option' + lowercase 'L' writes the @-sign.
> Is it possible to remap that to 'Hyper' + lowercase 'L' ?

:wave: Hi @chbroecker:  Thanks for trying out this repo! I'll try to help.

If you make a copy of [`hyper-apps-defaults.lua`](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/blob/72998c1106b203d50fc79a4fb363484042937df1/hammerspoon/hyper-apps-defaults.lua) and name it `hyper-apps.lua`, you can customize Hyper Mode to your liking. Then, if you make the changes shown below, you can remap <kbd>hyper</kbd>+<kbd>l</kbd> to type a lowercase `l`. Does that help?

```diff
--- a/hammerspoon/hyper-apps.lua
+++ b/hammerspoon/hyper-apps.lua
@@ -3,6 +3,11 @@
 -- To launch _your_ most commonly-used apps via Hyper Mode, create a copy of
 -- this file, save it as `hyper-apps.lua`, and edit the table below to configure
 -- your preferred shortcuts.
+
+function exampleFunction()
+  hs.eventtap.keyStrokes('l')
+end
+
 return {
   { 'a', 'iTunes' },            -- "A" for "Apple Music"
   { 'b', 'Google Chrome' },     -- "B" for "Browser"
@@ -11,6 +16,7 @@ return {
   { 'e', 'Atom' },              -- "E" for "Editor"
   { 'f', 'Finder' },            -- "F" for "Finder"
   { 'g', 'Mailplane 3' },       -- "G" for "Gmail"
+  { 'l', exampleFunction },
   { 's', 'Slack' },             -- "S" for "Slack"
   { 't', 'iTerm' },             -- "T" for "Terminal"
 }
```

Note: You'll need to reload your Hammerspoon config each time you change the code.

Turns out the edge cases are that each input device manages its own muted/un-muted state, whereas my change to the push-to-talk extension here assumes the muted/un-muted state is global.

The right approach looks like using [`hs.audiodevice:watcherCallback(fn)`](http://www.hammerspoon.org/docs/hs.audiodevice.html#watcherCallback), but the callbacks look like they need to be registered per-`audiodevice`, but I'm not sure how best to start a new watcher when net-new input sources are enabled‚Ä¶

Edit: Looks like [`hs.audiodevice.watcher`](http://www.hammerspoon.org/docs/hs.audiodevice.watcher.html) is probably what I want, because it's watching the global state, not a per-device state.

> I'm curious if you think it's still worth it to use vim or not ...

That's a very personal choice. üòá  There are probably as many opinions on that matter as their are programmers. üò¨ 

With that in mind, I can only offer [my personal opinion](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/tree/f76f389d1667fa3767aad50cf658c6cce22fcaf1#more-useful-for-me). Personally, I use [Atom](https://atom.io/) as my primary editor, and I use [(S)uper (D)uper Mode](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/tree/f76f389d1667fa3767aad50cf658c6cce22fcaf1#super-duper-mode)'s vim keys to navigate left/down/up/right in Atom and in every other app on my Mac. As [noted in the README](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/tree/f76f389d1667fa3767aad50cf658c6cce22fcaf1#toward-a-more-useful-keyboard), I value that consistency:

> I want the _same_ (more useful) keyboard in every app.
> Ubiquitous keyboarding.
> Muscle memory.
> [Don't make me think][don't-make-me-think].
>
> How do I go to the beginning of the line in this app?
> The same way I go to the beginning of the line in _every_ app!
> Don't make me think.
>
> How do I go to the top of the file/screen/page in this app?
> The same way I...
> Well, you get the point.

:smile:

That said, for those times when I'm ssh'ed into a server, and there's no Atom in sight, I find it valuable to be able to get around and perform basic editing in vim. Vim is definitely my preferred *terminal-based* editor.

I hope this helps.

[don't-make-me-think]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don't_Make_Me_Think

I suspect you're running into a [keyboard ghosting issue](https://www.microsoft.com/appliedsciences/content/projects/AntiGhostingExplained.aspx):

> "Ghosting" is the problem that some keyboard keys don't work when multiple keys are pressed simultaneously. The key presses that don't show up on the computer or seem to have disappeared are said to have been "ghosted". On most keyboards, even some that are explicitly marketed as "Anti-Ghosting," this happens with many three key combinations.

You can use an [online tool](https://www.microsoft.com/appliedsciences/content/projects/KeyboardGhostingDemo.aspx) to test whether your keyboard is capable of simultaneously sending `s` + `d` + `space` + `h`. To perform the test:

1. Quit Hammerspoon
1. Open https://www.microsoft.com/appliedsciences/content/projects/KeyboardGhostingDemo.aspx
1. Click the keyboard image on that page
1. Hold down `s` and verify that you see the `s` key highlighted on the keyboard
1. Hold down `d` and verify that you see the `d` key highlighted on the keyboard
1. Hold down `space` and verify that you see the `space` key highlighted on the keyboard
1. Hold down `h` and verify that you see the `h` key highlighted on the keyboard

On my Kinesis Freestyle 2, all of the steps above work. However, some keyboards are incapable of sending all four of those keystrokes.

I suspect keyboard ghosting is the source of this problem, so I'm going to close this issue. 3fb5e77f7c5e6b5d7cb3e247ac016016d17ea096 adds support for "(S)uper (D)uper Mode" on macOS Sierra. Most of the [pre-Sierra features](https://github.com/jasonrudolph/keyboard/blob/e19948b26cc569e41637d60a5357d1d2e46669eb/screenshots/karabiner-change-key-config-02.png) are available:

>	**(S)uper (D)uper Mode**
>
> To activate, push the **s** and **d** keys simultaneously and hold them down. Now you're in (S)uper (D)uper mode. It's like a secret keyboard _inside_ your keyboard. (Whoa.) It's optimized for keeping you on the home row, or very close to it. Now you can:
>
> - Use **h**/**j**/**k**/**l** for **up**/**down**/**left**/**right** respectively
> - Use **a** for **alt** (AKA **option**)
> - Use **f** for **command**
> - Use **space** for **shift**
> - Use **a** + **j**/**k** for **page up**/**page down**
> - Use **i**/**o** to move to the previous/next tab
> - Use **a** + **h**/**l** to move to previous/next word in most apps (but not yet in iTerm2)

Prior to Sierra, this functionality :point_up: relied on Karabiner's [Simultaneous VI Mode](https://github.com/tekezo/Karabiner/blob/8fe38da09ff0f05e20e0f4cde80258435bfcad47/src/core/server/Resources/include/checkbox/simultaneouskeypresses_vi_mode.xml). Since [Karabiner-Elements doesn't yet support Simultaneous VI Mode](https://github.com/tekezo/Karabiner-Elements/issues/153), this pull request implements the functionality via Hammerspoon.

---

13:10:17     hotkey: Disabled hotkey F20

@JasonEtco If this pull request will be merged with new assert feature - could you please publish new version of actions-toolkit to npm?

@likern üëã can you explain what this would be used for/why its needed? I'm not sure I understand the need for it in this library, it seems more like a helper method that's very specific to your use-case, but I'd love to hear more.

> @likern üëã can you explain what this would be used for/why its needed? I'm not sure I understand the need for it in this library, it seems more like a helper method that's very specific to your use-case, but I'd love to hear more.

Yes, of course. If we use actions-toolkit in TypeScript we want to check types and  narrow down types.

There is a common pattern for that in JavaScript: using `assert` functions. This is especially useful in scripts, where in branches we just exit with failure. And main branch for successful path.
But TypeScript can't understand that we did checks.

```ts
// get version from inputs, it has type string | undefined
const version: string | undefined = '0.63.2'
assert (version !== undefined, 'Invalid version')
const str: string = version // TypeScript didn't understand that in assert we checked types. version is still string | undefined
```
If using with available API
```ts
// get version from inputs, it has type string | undefined
const version: string | undefined = '0.63.2'
if (version === undefined) {
  tools.exit.failure('version is undefined')
}

const str: string = version // TypeScript didn't understand that common pattern. version is still string | undefined
```

For that case TypeScript added assertion control flow analysis support https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/32695

> Thanks for that @likern. But I'm not clear on why regular old `assert` doesn't do what you want? It seems that https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/32695 added support for TypeScript being aware of `assert` possibly exiting.
> 
> To be honest, this seems like a very specific use-case, one that I'd hesitate to add to a library like actions-toolkit. I'd recommend just using a helper function in your own app code to do the same thing:
> 
> ```ts
> function isTruthy (tools: Toolkit, condition: boolean, msg?: string) {
>   if (!condition) {
>     tools.exit.failure(msg ?? `Assertion for value ${condition} is not truthy`)
>   }
> }
> ```

Yes, that's possible solution. But I've decided to make pull request exactly as exit functions merely do the same. They just wrap Node.js `process.exit()`. 

The only they do on top of that is logging messages with different log level. I thought if you've added them you wanted to have unified high-level API and, possibly, do not interact with broad low-level API.

The same intention behind assertion function. Instead of throwing exceptions as Node.js asset do, worrying about broad Node.js Assert API or fighting with type guards it allows do this in s simple way.

Not many developers know assert function doesn't reduce type. Moreover assertion functions are not well known.

But, of course, if you hesitate to accept this pull request I will use my own branch, no problems.
I'm going to merge this - I'd love to hear thoughts on its usefulness, but _I_ think _I'll_ use it, so I'm including it üòä

@JasonEtco I've been thinking about this and I'm not sure it's the right fix. It'd work for common use cases, but if you're trying to add a label to a `pull_request` it's going to give you the wrong payload.

Would it make sense to split `issue()` in to `issue()` and `pullRequest()` and let the consumer explicitly choose which they prefer?

tl;dr: Have two getters, `issue` and `pullRequest`. Also keep the fallback implementation already proposed to allow `pullRequest` to return `{issue_number: payload.pull_request.number}`

## More details

I can see two issues here:

### Where to pull the number from

This is covered by the PR in it's current state

### The format that we return the data in

I'd like to be able to do `...context.issue` or `...context.pullRequest` depending on if we're using an Issue or a PR endpoint.

`...context.issue` should use the implementation in this PR to extract `number` and return an `issue_number` key in the context. The value of `number` *may* come from `payload.pull_request.number` but it needs to be returned as `issue_number` if we're interacting with Issue features e.g. Labels

Hey @frontendphil, can you share your code? Js-yaml isn‚Äôt used by this library anymore, but if you were using the dependency directly you‚Äôll now need to install it directly.

That's weird :) The code is rather simple. 

```js
// entrypoint.js
const { Toolkit } = require('actions-toolkit')

const tools = new Toolkit()

const { owner, repo } = tools.context.repo
const { sha } = tools.context
const { status, message, context } = tools.inputs

tools.github.repos
  .createStatus({
    owner,
    repo,
    sha,
    state: status,
    description: message,
    context,
    target_url: `https://www.github.com/${owner}/${repo}/commit/${sha}/checks`,
  })
  .then(() => {
    tools.exit.success()
  })
  .catch(err => {
    tools.log.fatal(err)
    tools.exit.failure()
  })
```



```dockerfile
// Dockerfile
FROM node:slim

COPY package*.json ./

RUN npm ci

COPY entrypoint.js /entrypoint.js

ENTRYPOINT ["node", "/entrypoint.js"]
```

Ok great - now that I think about it, one-string args being parsed weirdly is actually a known bug. That's why [some actions have an entrypoint](https://github.com/actions/npm/blob/master/entrypoint.sh) like this:

```shell
#!/bin/sh
sh -c "npm $*"
```

So if its working as expected with an args array, I think the best we can do is clarify this behavior in the README üëå

You're using `tools.github` but there's no `GITHUB_TOKEN` to authenticate with. Add

```
secrets = ["GITHUB_TOKEN]

 to the `action "..." {}` block in the `main.workflow`.

I solved this problem. I was using `with` instead of `env`

```
name: AutoMerger

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]

jobs:
  release_labeler:
    name: Auto Merger
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: aaomidi/AutoMerge@master
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: "${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}"

```

Oh good point, yeah it should definitely still be optional (updated my above snippet). Also not sure if `=> Promise<void>` is better than `=> Promise<unknown>` or `any` ü§î

> Also not sure if => Promise<void> is better than => Promise<unknown> or any ü§î

I *think* `unknown` is right‚Äî`void` would probably work, but it's not technically correct (it's not that the callback *must* return no value, it's that we don't care). `unknown` means "we can't use this without a type assertion", which is safer than `any`, where we can use the value if we wanted to.

I wonder if a generic makes more sense, but that seems overcomplicated, since we don't plan on using the value.

Ok so I've given this a real review @macklinu - its really solid, the experience is üëå. The one thing I want to improve is the logging - we're using `console.log` and it looks kinda funny next to Enquirer's fancier, bold/green logs. Fortunately, we have `Signale` already available to us. Here's what it looks like in 9bbf52d: Unfortunately, this totally borks in tests - I've tracked it down to be caused by the mock `fs`, since Signale tries to use it internally. I'm actually happy this came up, because I'm not sure that mocking `fs` is a good thing anyway - it means we're relying on our mocked logic instead of how `fs` really works. So, I think we should update the tests to instead read/write to/from real files in a fixtures folder. It'll make for more realistic tests, despite being a little more effort to delete/create the files as needed.

I've opened this as a separate issue so that it doesn't get lost @banyan! I wanted to make sure I'm understanding your use-case.

I definitely agree that we should be exiting with a neutral status code `78` as per [this doc](https://developer.github.com/actions/creating-github-actions/accessing-the-runtime-environment/#exit-codes-and-statuses) - we can make use of the `exit.neutral()` method added in #39. I just wanted to highlight this:

> When an action returns this exit status, GitHub terminates all concurrently running actions and prevents any future actions from starting.

‚òùÔ∏è this is the behavior I'm looking for, without the side effect of the failed status. @banyan if you want to open a PR that'd be wonderful üòç

Trying to decide what kind of Semver change this'd be ü§î It wouldn't affect actions being used on GitHub, but might throw an error in users' tests. My inclination is to bump the patch version, but I'm worried that might cause consumers of the library's tests to fail, despite those actions working in practice. That said, I don't want to bump major versions for such a small change.

Any thoughts @swinton?

Yeah. Good question. I think it‚Äôs a breaking change but I understand you not wanting to bump the major version for such a small change.

@swinton just for your information - I've been waiting for at least one more breaking change to get this in, and #61 has come! So I'm merging this into a v2 branch with #61, and intend to publish the two PRs as a `@beta` tag for a little bit as I try it out with some actions.

Hi @swinton! Thank you for opening this - I really grappled with this decision. I'm happy to talk through it and properly `throw` (and even go so far as to `process.exit(1)`) - so here's my reasoning for how it is now, let me know what you think.

I had it warn rather than throw because of tests. I didn't want users of the library to always need to define every one of those env vars just to make their tests pass. Also, its for running actions code locally - I can run my code as a Node process without having to set all those env vars (which would be cumbersome as inline CLI arguments, or you'd need `dotenv`).

Definitely open to opinions here - I'm not 100% convinced either way honestly.

Iiiiiiinteresting. Thanks for the clear description üôè The reliability of knowing that your implementation is correct makes a lot of sense.

> Interesting point. For what it's worth, when running locally I typically send in environment variables with `docker run -e`, i.e. in a simple `run.sh` I have:

I might steal this and put it into the [bootstrap script](https://github.com/JasonEtco/actions-toolkit#bootstrap-a-new-action) - it looks really handy and would avoid a "why isn't my thing working oh its because I'm missing this env var."

I'm convinced! Will make it throw üëç possibly with an option to just warn in the constructor.

@swinton üëã I'm here to report that I reverted #41 in #70 üòÖ I discovered that some environment variables are not present in every event, so to depend on the existence of some but not all is as unreliable as none (that's confusing but I think it's correct). I also encountered [some friction](https://github.com/JasonEtco/actions-toolkit/pull/62#issuecomment-475094905) while using this in `v2.0.0-beta.1` - this was expected, but still not a great experience.

I'm going to close this issue because after investigating it and trying it out, I don't believe that the predictability is worth the friction, especially because `actions-toolkit` is a good way to _start_ writing Actions, where newcomers to the platform aren't familiar with the nuances of where the `event.json` lives, what env vars do what, etc.

Oh by the by @swinton  - this may or may not work for your use-case, but you can [define what events your Action is designed to be triggered by](https://github.com/JasonEtco/actions-toolkit#event-optional), which would help prevent `undefined` events!

> To clarify [#17 (comment)](https://github.com/JasonEtco/actions-toolkit/issues/17#issuecomment-458245263), are you stating that the only event a command can respond to is the `issue_comment` event and that the docs should explicitly state that?

Yeah, it'd be to avoid a "gotcha" where folks use the API in an action that cannot, by definition, trigger the command. I'd want to avoid people accidentally thinking that a `push` might trigger a `/command` üòÅ

Sweet!

> Is there anywhere specifically you currently know of for documentation on such.

Unfortunately not - the difficulty of testing Actions is one of the main reasons I wanted to write this library. [`create-an-issue`](https://github.com/JasonEtco/create-an-issue/blob/master/entrypoint.js) is a good example of a workaround - most of the functionality is outside of the main entrypoint (see `IssueCreator`), so its easier to write tests for the actual business logic. What it doesn't do is test the entire action, in its Docker container, with all of the context of previous workflows' effects. So - not a solved problem just yet I think!

Is this thing broken now

I've done some light investigating (so my conclusion here might be wrong). It seems that this bot only checks the files changed in the *last* commit pushed, not *since* the last push.

Namely this series of actions will result in the bug:
1. Add a TODO to file `A`.
2. Commit file `A`.
3. Change file `B`.
4. Commit file `B`.
5. Push both changes.

After you push the bot will check the files changed in the *last* commit (the one on file `B`) and thus won't ever see the TODO in file `A`.

Hello! Thanks for the kind words ‚ù§Ô∏è The current behavior for non-master branches is to post comments in a pull request - so if the branch has an open PR, the TODOs will be posted there, and created as issues when the PR is merged. Does that work for your use-case?

If not, I think that providing a list of branches, or a RegEx (including a `*` option), would be a nice addition. Something like:

```yaml
todo:
  # Specific branches
  branches:
    - master
    - dev
   
  # Any branch
  branches: *

  # RegEx
  branches: dev/*
```

Yes that would be an even better idea than mine.
Thanks for the workaround this works sort of, though in our code base, we often have issues that we want to fix (from code review e.g.) before merging into dev or master.

Thanks for opening @C-Fergus üôè the change in #242 caused issues with keywords that have a preceding `@`; if you remove that you'll be able to use a custom keyword.

```diff
todo:
-  keyword: @makeAnIssue
+  keyword: makeAnIssue
```

There's a test that confirms this behavior:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/b4bf28cea7191b4f6094c4da6b7ba8f05554cbba/tests/push-handler.test.js#L125-L130

Hey @roblabla - thanks for opening this! I'm not sure I understand what this change accomplishes. Can you elaborate on what the intended use is after this change? If you could add a test showing it off that'd help as well.

So Github comments have this annoying rule where it's not your usual markdown, it has an additional weirdness where linebreaks in the comment will cause a linebreak in the rendered version (in normal markdown, a linebreak in source will not result in a linebreak in the rendered document - you need to end the line with two spaces to get that).

To fix this annoyance, I had done a PR that used a simple heuristic to join all lines that were not separated by an empty lines. This works okay for normal text, but will break badly for code blocks - see [here](https://github.com/sunriseos/SunriseOS/issues/481#issue-495183124).

To fix that, this PR uses showdown, which can turn markdown to html and back. The interesting thing is that the markdown returned from doing this has all paragraphs on a single line with no line breaks inserted, which is exactly what we want to send to the github comment!

I'll try to add a test when I have some time.

Gotcha - thanks for the explanation! The comment in the issue you linked should definitely be rendered differently, with the code block. I'm not sure that converting it to HTML then to Markdown is the only way to go though; TODO should simply be the messenger, and not alter the contents of a comment if possible. Instead, I'd investigate why those individual `// BODY` lines are being concatenated into one line in the first place.

In [this GraphQL query](https://developer.github.com/v4/explorer/?query={%0A%20%20repository(owner%3A%20%22sunriseos%22%2C%20name%3A%20%22SunriseOS%22)%20{%0A%20%20%20%20issue(number%3A%20481)%20{%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20body%0A%20%20%20%20}%0A%20%20}%0A}%0A), you can see that the space between the code block and the text above it only has one newline character; I believe that that's the issue we should be solving.

That's likely [this line](https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/pull/232/files#diff-44351e5208066e14f1f07c6cc43b8659L24), where we call `.trim()`; I don't remember why that's there, but it might be worth removing.

Hiya üëã This is unfortunately expected behavior; because TODO acts on string matching instead of language ASTs, there's no way for it to know what is and isn't a comment for every single language. So in cases like this, it's looking for `ANYTHING <KEYWORD> <TITLE>`, where `TITLE` is a wildcard match.

I'd recommend using multiline comments:

```html
<!--
  @todo foobar
-->
```

I realize that's not ideal, but that's the tradeoff to be language agnostic. Hope that helps!

Hey folks - thanks for opening this üôè I see the issue here, but its unfortunately a little complicated. Because TODO operates on strings, not ASTs, it relies on vague matching; so this PR would prevent comments like this from trigger an issue:

```
@todo ...
```

Because there's no space after the `@`, and its not the start of the line. `.*` will match it, albeit very aggressively. There should be a test for this behavior that would have failed.

For this case, it might be worth tightening up your configured keyword to `// TODO`:

```yaml
# .github/config.yml
todo:
  keyword: "// TODO"
```

Let me know if that helps!

Thank you for all the recent discussions @Pawper! ‚ú® Really great to talk through these things.

This one I have a quick answer to: I don't believe that this fits into todo. The goal of the app is to help people make notes for themselves quickly, in a long-term way, without losing context and getting distracted from their code. Introducing features that require thought, planning and (usually) switching over to GitHub to identify the name of the project/milestone, would hamper that experience. Plus, with workflow stuff like that, there's no end - and todo would become more and more complicated to use.

Hope that makes sense! I'm going to close this out, but I'm happy to reopen for further discussion if you'd like!

Thanks for kicking this off @Pawper! I've gone ahead and added a test, then passed that test. It required me to move some code around the push handler, to ensure that we weren't `return`-ing too early if an existing issue has been found.

I believe this is alright to deploy - I'll need to try it out locally just to be sure though.

Ah ok I've discovered an unfortunate scenario. Todo operates on the diff of a commit or PR - it does so for performance reasons, and its almost always plenty reliable. Unfortunately, this means that unless a matched line (a `TODO` comment) is found _in the diff_, the app won't pick up on changes to an existing comment's `BODY`.

I'm not really sure that this should be solved - this behavior is more involved than I'd like, and I don't want to compromise the current behavior by messing with the diff parsing ü§î
Ah, well, maybe something for a future deep dive. Thanks for having a go at it, and for the guidance üôÇ

It's been assigned to @Pawper because they committed the code." ```

@JasonEtco Thanks for the quick replies. Yes, the issue is that the checkboxes do not render with ```
```. However even if ```
``` worked, I feel it isn't much more elegant than the empty ```@body``` lines. Ideally there would be some sensible syntax without having to use workarounds like these. Either seamless multi-line body, e.g.: ``` /** * @todo This issue has a task list * @body Here's the body text * @body - [ ] Here's an unchecked task * @body - [x] This one's done */ ``` Or the initial suggestion: ``` /** * @todo This issue has a task list * @body Here's the body text * @[ ] Here's an unchecked task * @[x] This one's done */ ``` Thanks again, really appreciate this app in what I'm figuring is a VSCode-GitHub-Todo-Automation (VGTA?) workflow üòÅ

There's some previous conversation on why the first suggestion (multi-line `@body`s) won't work: https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/issues/93. I'm open to exploring this more to see if we can make it work though!

As for the latter - I'm really hesitant to add any special syntax. TODO operates on keywords, not any fancy AST parsing - this lets it be language agnostic. Adding syntax like `@[ ]` makes sense for parsing JSDoc comments, but won't have reliable equivalents in any other language or documentation tool.

Sorry, I'm a bit of an amateur, but I'm doing my best to keep up! I do see what you mean - ```@body``` is only JSDoc and TODO supports other contexts as well. There is also the idea that task lists are part of the body of the issue.

Anyway, I can go ahead with the current functionality and I'm going to delete the comments once the task list is all checked off (which I think will close issues in a future release?), so it's not seriously problematic or anything. Maybe just more encouragement for your exploration of multi-line ```@body```s.

Sorry, just read #189. Closing.

I understand that there are many ways to avoid this problem such as modifying the one-line comment to multi-line comment, or like changing the settings of todobot. But I believe as long as todobot supports `C`, it should handle this thing without bothering changing the source code. I almost know nothing about building Github bot or javascript, so I'd really appreciate it if anyone can help fix this!

Hey @tjysdsg - thanks for opening this. Frankly, there's not a lot that can be done here without targeting these cases very specifically.

todo parses the diff as a string, not as a language AST - this is to be language agnostic. That means that it has no concept of comments: where they start _or end_. So, we can certainly say "if the title ends with `*/`, remove it" - but that may break other use cases where that's intentional and used in a different language. I'm open to discussing it, or just adding a `trimFromEnd` config or something.
Got it, I'll just change my config for now.
I'm going to close this for now @tjysdsg because there is nothing actionable, but if you're still interested in talking about a `trimFromEnd` config feel free to open another issue!
Going to call this closed by #194 - I'll continue to monitor though and see where we're at in a couple of days.

@k1o0 it appears that that PR's diff is too large: `136635/100000` (`your pr / the limit`). I instituted a limit to the size of diffs that would be parsed because overly large diffs (like people committing minified files) were causing downtime (see #194). Awesome, thanks for kicking this off @roblabla! Your implementation was spot on, and I really appreciate that you added some tests!

The one failing test was because the body keyword was also found in the body itself; this was throwing off the RegEx after the `(?<body>)` group became optional. I'll tackle that edge-case in a followup PR, so for now I just modified the test.

I also made some tweaks to the RegEx - thanks for flagging the performance concern. `.*` is basically `.+?`, since it matches "0 or more of anything" so that's a little win. I also moved some `?` around to be a little cleaner.

Lastly, I tweaked the for loop to use a `for...of` and eventually `.join()`, adding in `\n` or spaces where necessary. It might not be as performant, but its a lot easier to reason about when looking at the code. Eventually this might be better off as a concatenating string, but because of the index looking on line 16 its useful to be an array.

If those changes sound good to you I'll deploy this so we can try it out for real üéâ
Everything looks good! And yeah haha, my Javascript is *reeaally* rusty. Forgot about `for of` :P. I think this is ready to go :tada:

No worries at all - thats kind of the whole point of PRs, to get changes from good to great üòä I've deployed this PR, I'll try it out myself but if you could give it quick check to verify that'd be great! Then this should be good to merge üöÄ

Thanks for this suggestion. I'd be open adding support for multiple continuous lines that match the body keyword, but a couple of questions first (not saying you need to answer them, just that we need to ask 'em):

* How will we concatenate the lines? Do we keep line breaks consistent with how it is in the code, or `.join(' ')`?
* Do we require that continuous lines match the _exact_ same body keyword, or do they only need to match the RegEx (which might include multiple keywords, or be case-insensitive)?

Would you be up for starting a PR?

For the first question, I don't have a strong preference. I like what the normal markdown (not GFM) does, which is to join with a space for single linebreaks, and with a \n for double linebreaks. This makes it easy to read both the source file and the resulting document, at the cost of a bit more complicated "rendering" logic. E.G.

```
this is a
test
```

results in "this is a test", but

```
this is a

test
```

results in "this is a\ntest".

-----------

As for your second question: I think whichever is easier on the implementation works :P. I think it'd be easier to just require each line to match the RegEx. Then we can just keep running the Regex on all lines until it stops matching. 

I'll try to get a PR up.
Great, those both sound good to me. Thanks for talking through it!

I'm stuck with a bit of an odd problem:

```
BODY: Test
BODY:
BODY: Another test
```

This currently does not get matched, as the BODY *requires* spaces after the `:` to get matched. I thought I'd change the regex to make the whole right side of the `:` optional:

`.+(?<keyword>PIZZA|text):?(?:\s(?<body>.*))?`

This turns out to break one of the tests, namely "text This is a text". Example: https://regex101.com/r/A1FCUV/1

I'm not great at regex by any measure. I could add a lazy qualifier, but I'm very afraid this would negatively affect performance in terrible ways. I'm not sure how this could be fixed, any idea would be appreciated.
There was a little lag, but it worked like a charm.

Hey thanks for the note, and for closing the issue. I'm surprised it took _that long_, but it does take a bit of time to parse large diffs - especially those that have a number of TODOs. This is kind of intentional, to ensure that duplicate TODO comments/issues aren't generated (so we create one, then give it a hot second before checking if one by that name already exists).

Thanks for the issue @rgbkrk üôè 

I think this is a race condition, where TODO generates a comment, but at the same time it gets another event and checks if that comment has been created - it all happens so fast that the GitHub API says no.

I have a possible solution, which is to basically delay any `GET` requests for a full second - I've done this in other applications to counter replication lag, but it'd work here as well. Will try to get a fix out shortly!

You're asking about Todo removing comments for things that don't exist after a rebase? No arguments here - however, I don't think it has a huge impact, since it'd only act once per repo. The thing is, Todo's current implementation specifically acts on diffs - this is for performance mostly. So things would have to change a lot for that to be viable.

@JasonEtco 
What I gather is this: 
The PR handler is run when a PR is opened or closed.
There can't be duplicate comments in either of those cases.
So what is the point of checking for duplicate comments.
I realise that the addition of the duplicate comment checking code to push-handler won't solve the problem. What needs to be done I reckon is to listen for push events on PR's and then run the duplicate comment checking code.

That clears things up.
I will try and see why things are not working as they should then.
Back to the drawing board :male_detective:

@JasonEtco ready for review.

@JasonEtco how's that?

Cool @OmgImAlexis thanks.

I'm open to this - I'd love to have a config option that takes a RegEx, something like:

```yaml
exclude: /.*\/dist\/.*/

# or

ignore: /.*\/dist\/.*/
```

I don't currently have the bandwidth to add new features to this project, but if you'd like to open a PR I will happily work with you on it.
If you could try and link me to where I should look at adding the filters that'd help a lot.

Sure thing. There's currently a check to see if a parsed out filename is the config file; I think it'd make sense to add the check here:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/f59f365ec5adc3c9ee741ce2d5ffda5cbbe58524/src/pull-request-handler.js#L25

This could be rewritten to something like:

```js
if (parsed.filename === '.github/config.yml' || (config.exclude && parsed.filename.test(new RegExp(config.exclude))) {
  continue
}
```

This check currently exists in three places - the PR handler, the push handler and the PR merged handler.

## Version **4.10.0** just got published. Your tests are passing again with this version. [Explicitly upgrade to this version üöÄ](https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/compare/master...JasonEtco:greenkeeper%2Fwebpack-4.10.0)
Release Notes v4.10.0

Features

  • Export and import name strings in them wasm are mangled
  • Unused exports in wasm are removed (Tree Shaking)
    • Don't expect size improvements yet since there is not minimizer for WASM yet which does the Dead Code Elimination, which is the second part for this optimization
  • Direct WASM dependencies are enforced for:
    • functions imports with i64 parameters or return values
    • memory and table imports
  • generate shorter wasm runtime code

Bugfixes

  • generate correct initializer for imported globals in wasm
  • side-effect-free modules referenced by export * from are no longer including in the bundle
  • the side-effects optimization is now possible in incremental compilation
