`chunkDiff` separates one large diff into different chunks based on their file path. For example, if a commit modifies two files, that commit will still only have one diff - `chunkDiff` "chunks" the diff into pieces that are easier to parse as separate files, which is important when putting together the new issue body that contains a filename and code blob. That said, there is still a match loop within the string that `chunkDiff` returns:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/b1e49533b783fe8a345bc24aad32b47d625db6d2/src/push-handler.js#L28-L32

That said, I'm not sure why its only opening the first issue. Is this something you noticed in production, or while running the CLI (or both)?

I see where chunkDiff splits based off file path.
If I have 1 file with multiple new TODO's, it gets split into 1 single chunk.  I assume that's right?
Should parseChunk be receiving 1 TODO as match or all the TODO's from that file?

Currently the regex in push_handler matches like this (https://regexr.com/3naf7) and sends the whole thing to parseChunk.  parseChunk then only parses the first TODO.

I am currently running it locally.

> If I have 1 file with multiple new TODO's, it gets split into 1 single chunk. I assume that's right?

Yep thats right, each chunk represents one file. Note that this is not the same as Git's [hunk](https://www.bignerdranch.com/blog/using-git-hunks/) paradigm, which is separated by the `@@...@@` lines.

> Currently the regex in push_handler matches like this

Because the RegEx has the `g` global flag, it should be able to run repeatedly in a while loop until the `regex.exec(string)` returns `null`. `parseChunk` is called within that while loop, so it _should_ be run every time theres a match. I'll look into why it isn't doing that.

This should be resolve after the changes in #165 - I've observed some successful output from diffs that have multiple TODOs. Thanks everyone!

Hey @aes421 - I really appreciate the work you've done to track this down! I have been noticing some inconsistencies that users have been facing, but I haven't had time to look into it or respond to those issues. You've clearly spend some time digging into it, and that's awesome.

As you know, the difference between the two RegEx's you've linked to removes the `$` character, which matches until the end of a line (in multiline mode). It appears that some diffs' contents can actually start on the same line as the `@@...@@` line, which contains line numbers and diff metrics. That explains the inconsistency, since it doesn't always happen, but when it does it totally cancels out the match.

If you'd like to open a pull request removing that character, that'd be great. I'm curious to see if the tests still pass, and if the output stays consistent. If so, I'd be happy to merge.

Hey @hawkins! Thanks for the report!

> Not sure what I did to cause this

You did nothing wrong - this is a bug in TODO that I've seen before, but haven't had time to solve (and kept forgetting to open an issue for).

TLDR, it occurs when there are two hunks in the same file in a diff. That looks like:

```
diff --git a/README.md b/README.md
index 8f65799..f4be99b 100644
--- a/README.md
+++ b/README.md
@@ ... line numbers ... @@
+ changes
- other changes
@@ ... other line numbers ... @@
+ changes
- other changes
```

I believe that right now its basing the line numbers on the _first_ hunk, rather than the _nearest_ (most relevant) hunk numbers.

Totally open to PRs on this, I won't have time to fix it for a few weeks - if you're a RegEx champ then this is for you üòâ
Well you know I'm no champ, you've seen me work with RegEx plenty recently üòâ  I'll gladly give this a look though! Thanks for the lightning fast feedback! üëè

Thinking about this some more, I think it may require more than just a RegEx change - might be best to split hunks by `@@...@@` lines, then parse those hunks. If modifying the RegEx to grab the nearest hunk numbers is possible that'd be best, but it may not be.

I was thinking it looked like a bit more than a regex change at first glance the other day, too; I'm hoping to take a stab at this sometime tomorrow or this weekend, maybe even while streaming if I can come up with a strategy for tackling it first, since a few more eyes on it could help out. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Sweet, this is a really great start, thanks @koddsson! You covered everything, with the template and the tests üòç I'll try it out locally and figure out why the test is failing.

Also, I'm hoping to fit this same functionality into the `pull-request-merge-handler.js`. Your setup looks ‚ú® so it shouldn't be tough once we get this first test passing.

To verify that the new functionality is working, I went ahead and created a separate test for closing an issue alone, with a new test to create _and_ remove and issue in the same diff. The latter is still failing (it's the same as your original test) but the more specific test is passing which is nice. Not sure why, but I'll investigate some more.

The format of how TODO parses diffs and identifies new "todo"s has changed dramatically as of #165 - it's way way easier to do this now. I'm going to close this PR @koddsson because sifting through the conflicts just won't be fun, but this is still a thing I want to do, and your PR will be a great reference for the new implementation ‚ù§Ô∏è

Heck yes, I‚Äôve wanted this for awhile, just haven‚Äôt gotten around to doing it. Right now it uses the `+` character in diffs to identify new todos; we can use the inverse `-` to remove them, with the same regex (and capture group the -/+). Pull request welcome üòò otherwise I‚Äôll probably be able to work on it mid April.

@JasonEtco

Cool!

---

One thing I could not wrap my head around was this regex:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/f7914a00ff5146dbc93738612fbbf9f558fb7086/src/utils/chunk-diff.js#L18

Could you give me the what-what on this? From context it seems like this is the place where we find `TODO` comments that have been added and we return those diffs?

---

Here's another regex that I think is responsible for finding all the added (`+`) `TODO` items.

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/f7914a00ff5146dbc93738612fbbf9f558fb7086/src/utils/parse-chunk.js#L24

The rest of the file parses the code around it to gather up info to post as a issue?

---

So I think I mostly need to change these files and change the regex to find removed lines as well, mark those somehow as being removed and then when detecting duplicates I can close those if there is a duplicate?

What do you mean @koddsson, those RegExes are all so clear and understandable `/sarcasm`!

The first one, in `chunk-diff.js`, takes a whole diff and returns an array of chunks. So for example, given this:

```diff
diff --git a/bin/todo.js b/bin/todo.js
index bc649d0..666960b 100755
--- a/bin/todo.js
+++ b/bin/todo.js
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
 
 const program = require('commander')
 const chalk = require('chalk')
-const GitHubAPI = require('github')
+const octokit = require('@octokit/rest')()
diff --git a/package.json b/package.json
index 8b30cb6..8768e00 100644
--- a/package.json
+++ b/package.json
@@ -41,9 +41,9 @@
   },
   "dependencies": {
     "@google-cloud/logging-bunyan": "^0.7.0",
+    "@octokit/rest": "^15.1.7",
     "chalk": "^2.3.1",
     "commander": "^2.14.1",
-    "github": "^14.0.0",
```

It'd split it into two chunks, one for changes to `bin/todo.js` and one for changes to `package.json`. This is mostly for ease-of-handling, and to have more determinable file names and line numbers.

---

That second RegEx parses a match, so when the overarching RegEx finds a TODO in a chunk in a diff, it'll send that chunk over to `parse-chunk.js`. You'll notice at the top I define variables from the capture groups:

https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/f7914a00ff5146dbc93738612fbbf9f558fb7086/src/utils/parse-chunk.js#L10-L18

Those come from this RegEx that actually parses the chunks and captures the right stuff:
https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/blob/f7914a00ff5146dbc93738612fbbf9f558fb7086/src/utils/handler-setup.js#L14

Somewhere in there is `^(\\+)` - that's capturing the prefix (and there's even a variable for it in `chunk-diff.js`!). I was originally planning to treat removals differently, so at one point that was actually `^([-+])`, allowing for either prefix. That's where I'd start identifying the different lines.

Happy to talk through more of this, it gets a little messy with all the RegEx, but I think that with the variable `prefix` it's already a good ways into knowing when a TODO is removed - just need to do something with that information üôå

@JasonEtco 

Awesome! I made a change here but my tests are failing because the regular expression capture group(?) isn't picking up both TODO comments in the file and I don't know enough regex to change it üò≠ 

Here's the PR: https://github.com/JasonEtco/todo/pull/130

I loaded the regex up on regex101.com and tried fiddling with it but I can't seem to capture both comments when the regex has `^([-+])`. Here's the link to the regex loaded in regex101: https://regex101.com/r/O5hUJr/1

Note that if I change it to be `^([-])`, the test will run green üòÑ (but others will obviously fail)

> I loaded the regex up on regex101.com and tried fiddling with it but I can't seem to capture both comments when the regex has ^([-+]).

`^diff --git a\/.+ b\/(.+)[\s\S]+?^@{2}.+\+(\d+).+@{2}$([\s\S]+?(^(-|\\+).*(@todo|TODO)(?:[:-\s]+)?\s(.*))[\s\S]+)` . This captures both comments. Wonder why `[-+]` is not working though. :thinking:
Just wondering if there is any progress on this? Would be quite a useful feature. ‚ù§Ô∏è
@NilsDannemann I've started on an implementation in #184 - it needs some work still though. Feel free to follow along there!

This would be super helpful to have. Re: RegEx readability - I‚Äôve done them like this in the past and I find it helps myself and others who come back to that code later:

```js
  /* eslint-disable prettier/prettier */
  const twigRegex = new RegExp(
    "(?<=" + // begin lookahead assertion; these patterns must appear before and will not be included in result
      "(include|extends|embed) " + // any of these words and then a space
      "[\"|']" + // either `"` or `'`
    ")" + // end lookahead assertion
    "(.*\.twig)" // this will be captured as result. any character `.` infinite times `*` followed by a literal period `\.` and then `twig`
    , 'g'); // Regex flags - `g`: global
  /* eslint-enable prettier/prettier */
```

Release Notes v6.1.0 ‚Äì 2018-03-21

Enhancements

  • Do you love Probot and GraphQL? Well good news for you! Now you can use them together! Be warned: this is experimental. See the docs to get started and share your feedback. (#472)

  • An error will now be raised if there are several .pem files in your app directory. Set PRIVATE_KEY_PATH to specify which one you want to use. (#441)

  • Updated Node.js minimum version required to 8.3.0. This was a requirement for apps to run before, but the check was only looking for 7.7. (#464)

  • Switched from github-webhook-handler to @octokit/webhooks. You shouldn't notice any changes, but let us know if your app has any weird symptoms (#462)

  • Updated @octokit/rest to version 15.2.0

This is a great idea. I'm refactoring the core internals right now, and this should come after. Noting for posterity:

You can get the diff of a PR:

```
curl https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/gr2m/octokit-rest-browser-experimental/pull/19.diff
```

[A ~quick~ RegEx](https://regexr.com/3kqnq) to match keywords, file names and titles in diffs:

```
/^diff --git a\/.+ b\/(.+)[\s\S]+@@ -?(\d+)[\s\S]+(^([+\-]).*(@todo|TODO)(?:[:-\s]+)?(.*))[\s\S]+^diff --git/gm 

Capture groups:
[1]: File name
[2]: Line number start of diff section
[3]: Entire title line
[4]: -/+
[5]: Keyword
[6]: Title
```

In the check for duplicate issues, it previously also identified if a todo with the same name was in different files, and would create multiple issues accordingly. However, this created friction when people would move a todo from one file to another; it would create a new issue. I removed the same-file check, so now it _only_ checks if an issue with the same title exists.

Since I've made that change fairly recently, I'm going to wait it out and see if the change becomes a new source of friction. Thanks for letting me know!

Hey . I was going through this bug and had a few questions.
Should this action be the default for all cases?
For eg. If we have a body with 2 sentences,should the bot write a 2 line comment?
Or should there be a cut off number of sentences after which the bot multi lines the comment

I like the idea.
So what you propose is :
```
@todo : This is a sample comment.
@body : > Sample comment line 1.
Sample comment line 2.
Sample comment line 3.

Multline ends here
```
We could consider a special character or group of characters instead of an empty line to end the multiline if empty line is not desirable?

> We could consider a special character or group of characters instead of an empty line to end the multiline if empty line is not desirable?

Totally! That'd have to be something pretty obvious, but still small enough to not be annoying to look at in the code. It'd also need to ignore the entire line that that end character(s) is on, otherwise it'd also consider things like comment delimiters as part of the body.

There is another significant problem though; different languages have different comment syntax, and we don't want that to come into the body. For example:

```js
// BODY > Here
// and here
```

The body should be:

```
Here
and here
```

But unless there's some real smart comment syntax detection, it'd render as:

```
Here
// and here
```

``` Here // and here ``` Fixing this would require us to write code specific to different languages and I dont think that is feasible. Consider this. The user writes the comment in a single line. And whenever he/she wants a new line they insert a token like ```
``` or somethine along the same lines. Eg. ``` // BODY : Here
Here. ``` The body should be: ``` Here Here. ```

@rsarky using `
` tags should actually work already. Worth trying out to be certain, but that shouldn't require any more work; if thats the case, it should be documented that thats a possibility üìñ
I will test it to be sure.If it works I will document it.

I did a bit of testing the ```
``` tags aren't working. But I guess they aren't always supposed to work in markdown? AFAIK the markdown way of adding a new line is adding two spaces after you end a new line then you go to a new line. I tested doing the above too but it doesn't seem to work. It just appends everything into one line

@rsarky - **todo** doesn't do any markdown parsing; it's all left to GitHub. In other words, `
` works fine to start a new line on GitHub (you can try it out in an issue comment), but it isn't being sent correctly by **todo**, probably because `Handlebars` auto-escapes "dangerous" characters. I'm cool with removing the safety check there, provided we add some more validation so that its still "safe."
I think [https://stackoverflow.com/q/12331077/7570841](url) is exactly what we want?

Note quite; Handlebars will turn `
` into `<br>`, so we'd just need to either turn it back: ```js text.replace('<br>', '
') ``` Or don't sanitize the input at all (notice the triple curly braces instead of the normal two): ```md {{{ body }}} ``` The former is an extra calculation that the app has to do (not a huge deal), and the latter presents an a way for folks to inject malicious code. So I'm a üëç to the first option!

Ah that explains it, @JasonEtco! Thanks for getting on to this so quickly, by the way :)
Is their anyway to trigger todo to rescan the repository for the issue flags? Also, if I add a issue flag, like:
```
<!--
@todo Create Issue
@body Body
-->
```

Will it create a new issue if I commit this file again without removing the todo, or does it somehow keep track of which todos have already been made into an issue?

Here's how it all works:

It scans the commits made in a push. It reads the files changed or added in those commits, parses out the issues to generate, checks if they already exist (to prevent duplicates), then generates them. It works pretty similarly in a PR, but it makes comments instead of issues.

So to answer your two questions:

1. To trigger **todo**, just push changes to the files you want it to scan.
1. It will not create a new issue if the same one (based on the issue title and the file its in) already exists. If one does exist and is closed, it'll be reopened. If its already an open issue, nothing will happen :)

> Error: Failed to lookup view "probot.ejs" in views directory "/views"

Basically an error caused by bundling. The way it's transpiling the `probot` directory, the relative links to other directories is messed up. My lazy hack to transpile the probot dependency breaks it. Still looking for the best way to make webpack understand what I want it to do.
Ooooh @tcbyrd you're totally right. I'll put some more thinking towards a better webpack solution then (again), see if I can figure out any better way of doing it.

This may help:
https://webpack.js.org/guides/dependency-management/#require-context
> It allows you to pass in a directory to search, a flag indicating whether subdirectories should be searched too, and a regular expression to match files against.

Also just want to point out that `/stats` will need to work differently on Lambda. Currently the interval is one an hour. Max execution time for Lambda is 300 seconds. Is there any reason we couldn't just have the endpoint get the data when it's invoked? Alternatively, we can call a [schedule event](https://serverless.com/framework/docs/providers/aws/events/schedule/), but the question then becomes where do we store that data?

Ah that's a good point. The question of whether or not the refresh is necessary is probably best answered by @bkeepers; I see the use of it (to poll for popular installations), so I'm wondering if we can just pass a config option somehow to disable it.

Alternatively, we can copy-pasta the `/stats` endpoint logic into a separate route, but that feels hacky.

@JasonEtco I talked to @bkeepers about the stats endpoint earlier. Basically because of rate limiting and the way we have to build this data, a larger installation could take a while to build up the data and would have to make multiple calls. I'm thinking the "right" thing to get it working for now is to create a scheduled function that stores the results in an s3 bucket. Then the stats endpoint on lambda would just respond with that object. Thoughts? Effectively, we need a way to store the results so that it persists beyond the execution of the function.

> create a scheduled function that stores the results in an s3 bucket

That's an interesting solution. Can `serverless` also spin up an S3 bucket? Ideally, we'd want the cognitive overhead for this task to be as minimal as possible.

>Can serverless also spin up an S3 bucket?

Yes. In fact, it already does. The zip package and CloudFormation template it generates are stored in a bucket with the name of your serverless service, so the scheduled function could just use that existing resources. I'm going to play around with this idea today.
We're working on some overhauls to how we do serverless (using Typescript to compile Probot for us), so I'm going to close this until that's happened, since I'm sure much will change. üéâ

Hey @mattstratton, thanks for opening this up!

The duplicate issues shouldn't be a problem, I very recently made a change in how it detects existing issues of the same name. Now it stores metadata in the issue body and checks that rather than just the title. However, that change meant that it would dupe issues that did not have that metadata, ie whatever was there in the couple hours before the change was made.

There is a known issue with blobs where if the file is, for example, 10 lines long and the issue title is on the last line, it gets confused since there is no line 15 (the issue title plus the configed blobLines number). This is kind of a combination between a problem with **todo** and with GitHub, but it should be fixable here.

Do those two things answer your question? I'll leave this open for the second part of it until it's fixed.

Aha...I see how that can happen. And especially in this case. I'll go ahead and close this.

Cool tool!
Thanks üòÅ  I'll open up a separate issue for the blob lines part of your question, and I'm working on a fix as we speak üëç
@mattstratton should be fixed by #40, just deployed the changes as well. Let me know in #39 if you're still seeing this problem!

I think having a config to toggle this would make sense:

```yaml
todo:
  reopenClosed: true/false
```

`true` should be the default. I think this makes sense to be completed after #24 (implement search API) to be able to query for closed issues in addition to open ones.

When re-opening an issue, it should also comment saying:

```
This issue has been reopened because the `${config.keyword}` comment still exists in `${file}`, as of `${sha}`.

If this was not intentional, just remove the comment from your code. You can also set the [`reopenClosed`](...) config if you don't want this to happen at all anymore.
```
Should reopen only if the file is the same as well as the title.
